revision.text:
{{Year box}} '''1852 in sports''' describes the year's events in world sport.
==[[Boxing]]== '''Events''' * 21 August — [[John Morrissey]] defeats George Thompson in the 11th round at Mare Island, California and claims the Heavyweight Championship of America, which has been vacated by the now-retired [[Tom Hyer]]. His claim is not generally recognised at this time because of the prior claim by [[Yankee Sullivan]], who fought Hyer in 1849.<ref name="JM">[http://www.cyberboxingzone.com/boxing/morrisey.htm Cyber Boxing Zone – John Morrissey]. Retrieved on 8 November 2009.</ref> * [[Harry Broome]] retains the Championship of England but there is no record of any fights involving him in 1851.<ref name="HB">[http://www.cyberboxingzone.com/boxing/broome-h.htm Cyber Boxing Zone – Harry Broome]. Retrieved on 8 November 2009.</ref>
==[[Chess]]== '''Events''' * [[Adolf Anderssen]] and [[Jean Dufresne]] play the ''[[Evergreen Game]]'' in Berlin. Like Anderssen's ''[[Immortal Game]]'' of the previous year, it is an informal game.
==[[Cricket]]== '''Events''' * The [[United All England Eleven]] (UEE) is established as a rival to [[William Clarke (cricketer)|William Clarke's]] [[William Clarke's All-England Eleven|All-England Eleven]] (AEE). [[Jemmy Dean]] and [[John Wisden]] are the main organisers. Other players representing the UEE in its early years include [[John Lillywhite]], [[Tom Lockyer (cricketer)|Tom Lockyer]], [[James Grundy (cricketer)|James Grundy]], [[Frederick Miller (cricketer)|Frederick Miller]], [[Will Mortlock]] and [[Tom Sherman (cricketer)|Tom Sherman]]. * 27 July — [[John Sherman (cricketer)|John Sherman]] makes his final first-class appearance for [[Manchester Cricket Club|Manchester]] v. [[Sheffield Cricket Club|Sheffield]] at [[Hyde Park Ground]], [[Sheffield]]. His career has spanned a record 44 seasons from his debut at [[Lord's]] on 20 September 1809 when he played for Beauclerk's XI v. Ladbroke's XI. '''England''' * Most runs – [[Nicholas Felix]] 529 @ 18.24 (HS 70) * Most wickets – [[James Grundy (cricketer)|James Grundy]] 103 @ 8.83 (BB 7–?)
==[[Horse racing]]== '''England''' * [[1852 Grand National|Grand National]] – Miss Mowbray * [[1,000 Guineas Stakes]] – Kate * [[2,000 Guineas Stakes]] – [[Stockwell (horse)|Stockwell]] * [[Epsom Derby|The Derby]] – [[Daniel O'Rourke (horse)|Daniel O'Rourke]] * [[Epsom Oaks|The Oaks]] – Songstress * [[St. Leger Stakes]] – Stockwell
==[[Rowing (sport)|Rowing]]== '''The Boat Race''' * 3 April — [[Oxford University Boat Club|Oxford]] wins the 11th [[The Boat Race 1852|Oxford and Cambridge Boat Race]], a revival of the race last contested in 1849 '''Other events''' * 3 August — The first [[Harvard–Yale Regatta]] is a 2-length win for Harvard in a single eight-oar, two-mile race on [[Lake Winnipesaukee]], [[New Hampshire]]. The Yale club initiated this Race, and the next one in 1855, by challenge to the Harvard club.<ref name=150yrs>[http://www.gocrimson.com/sports/mcrew-hw/tradition/harvard-yale-regatta "Harvard–Yale Regatta – 150 Years of Tradition"]. Harvard Men's Heavyweight Crew. Retrieved 2013-05-10.</ref>
==References== {{Reflist}}
{{Sports by year 1851 – 1900}}
[[Category:Sports by year]] [[Category:1852 in sports| ]]

{{Year box}} '''1865 in sports''' describes the year's events in world sport.
==[[Association football]]== '''Events''' * [[Nottingham Forest F.C.|Nottingham Forest]], then called Forest FC, is founded in December by its parent hockey club. It is the third oldest club in the [[Football League]] after [[Notts County]] and [[Stoke City]]. Forest and Notts County play each other twice in the 1865–66 season so the Nottingham derby is the oldest fixture among teams playing in major association football leagues worldwide.
==[[Baseball]]== '''National championship''' * [[National Association of Base Ball Players]] champion – [[Brooklyn Atlantics]] '''Events''' * The champion [[Brooklyn Atlantics|Atlantic]] club of [[Brooklyn, New York]] wins all 18 matches, a two-season run with one tie. * In double contrast to the first war year 1861, [[NABBP|National Association]] membership remains low but baseball-season travel and competition increase.
==[[Boxing]]== '''Events''' * With [[Tom King (boxer)|Tom King]] having retired, the English Championship remains vacant.<ref>[http://www.cyberboxingzone.com/boxing/barenuk.htm Cyber Boxing Zone – English champions]. Retrieved on 8 November 2009.</ref> * American Champion [[Joe Coburn]] refuses to fight his challengers and the title is claimed by [[Bill Davis (boxer)|Bill Davis]], [[Mike McCoole]] and [[Jimmy Elliott]].<ref name="JC">[http://www.cyberboxingzone.com/boxing/coburn.htm Cyber Boxing Zone – Joe Coburn]. Retrieved on 8 November 2009.</ref> * 2 November — [[Jimmy Elliott]] is about to fight [[Bill Davis (boxer)|Bill Davis]] at Point Pelee Island in Canada when police intervene and the event is cancelled; the title remains vacant with the same three claimants.<ref name="JE">[http://www.cyberboxingzone.com/boxing/elliott.htm Cyber Boxing Zone – Jimmy Elliott]. Retrieved on 8 November 2009.</ref>
==[[Cricket]]== '''Events''' * 15–16 February — earliest inter-colonial match in the West Indies is [[Barbados cricket team|Barbados]] v. [[Guyana cricket team|Demerara (now Guyana)]] at Bridgetown; recognised as the start of West Indian [[first-class cricket]]. * 3 March — formation of [[Worcestershire County Cricket Club]]. * 22 June — [[W. G. Grace]], still only 16, makes his first-class debut playing for Gentlemen of the South v. Players of the South. * [[Thomas Humphrey]] is the first batsman to score 1,000 runs in an English first-class season. '''England''' * Most runs – [[Thomas Humphrey]] 1,223 @ 29.82 (HS 106) * Most wickets – [[James Lillywhite]] 87 @ 13.18 (BB 7–30)
==[[Golf]]== '''Major tournaments''' * [[1865 Open Championship|British Open]] – [[Andrew Strath]]
==[[Horse racing]]== '''England''' * [[1865 Grand National|Grand National]] – Alcibiade * [[1,000 Guineas Stakes]] – Siberia * [[2,000 Guineas Stakes]] – [[Gladiateur]] * [[Epsom Derby|The Derby]] – [[Gladiateur]] * [[Epsom Oaks|The Oaks]] – Regalia * [[St. Leger Stakes]] – [[Gladiateur]] '''Australia''' * [[Melbourne Cup]] – Toryboy '''Canada''' * [[Queen's Plate]] – Lady Norfolk
==[[Rowing (sport)|Rowing]]== '''The Boat Race''' * 8 April — [[Oxford University Boat Club|Oxford]] wins the 22nd [[The Boat Race 1865|Oxford and Cambridge Boat Race]]
==[[Rugby football]]== '''Events''' * Foundation of [[Bath Rugby|Bath RFC]] and [[Hull F.C.]]
==References== {{Reflist}}
{{Sports by year 1851 – 1900}}
[[Category:Sports by year]] [[Category:1865 in sports| ]]

{{Year box}} '''1884 in sports''' describes the year's events in world sport.
==[[American football]]== '''College championship''' * [[NCAA Division I FBS National Football Championship|College football national championship]] – [[Yale Bulldogs]] '''Events''' * [[Amos Alonzo Stagg]] enters [[Yale University]] as a [[divinity]] student and, a natural athlete, joins the university's football team. * 25 October — [[Yale Bulldogs]] defeat [[Dartmouth Big Green football|Dartmouth]] 113–0. This is the first college football game where one team scores over 100 points and also the first time one team scores over 100 points while the opposing team scores zero.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.cfbdatawarehouse.com/data/div_iaa/ivyleague/yale/yearly_results.php?year=1880 |publisher=[[College Football Data Warehouse]] |accessdate=April 4, 2011 |first=David |last=DeLassus |title=Yale Yearly Results (1880–1884) |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20100213154608/http://cfbdatawarehouse.com/data/div_iaa/ivyleague/yale/yearly_results.php?year=1880 |archivedate=February 13, 2010 |df= }}</ref> * 29 October — The next week, the [[Princeton Tigers]] outscore the [[Lafayette Leopards football|Lafayette Leopards]] by 140–0.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.cfbdatawarehouse.com/data/div_iaa/ivyleague/princeton/yearly_results.php?year=1880 |publisher=[[College Football Data Warehouse]] |accessdate=April 4, 2011 |first=David |last=DeLassus |title=Princeton Yearly Results (1880–1884) |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20121021084709/http://www.cfbdatawarehouse.com/data/div_iaa/ivyleague/princeton/yearly_results.php?year=1880 |archivedate=October 21, 2012 |df= }}</ref>
==[[Association football]]== '''England''' * [[1884 FA Cup Final|FA Cup final]] – [[Blackburn Rovers]] 2–1 [[Queen's Park F.C.|Queen's Park]] (Glasgow) at [[The Oval]]. Blackburn Rovers is the first extant club to win the FA Cup. * [[Everton F.C.|Everton]] moves as tenant to [[Anfield]], a newly enclosed ground off Anfield Road, Liverpool. * [[Derby County F.C.|Derby County]] founded by [[Derbyshire CCC]] to provide a winter activity for players and supporters. * [[Leicester City]] founded as Leicester Fosse. '''Scotland''' * [[1884 Scottish Cup Final|Scottish Cup final]] – [[Queen's Park F.C.|Queen's Park]] win by a [[Walkover (contest)|walkover]] after [[Vale of Leven F.C.|Vale of Leven]] fail to appear
==[[Baseball]]== '''National championship''' * Inauguration of the [[National League]] v. [[American Association (19th century)|American Association]] fixture, sometimes called the "Original [[World Series]]" – [[Providence Grays]] (NL) defeats [[New York Metropolitans]] (AA) 3 games to nil. '''Events''' * [[Ned Williamson]] hits 27 [[home run]]s for the [[Chicago White Stockings (1870–89)|Chicago White Stockings]], establishing a record that will last for 35 years. He nearly doubles the record of 14 set the [[1883 in baseball|season before]] by [[Harry Stovey]]. * [[Moses Fleetwood Walker]] becomes the first black American major league baseball player when he makes his [[American Association (19th century)|American Association]] league debut for the [[Toledo Blue Stockings]].
==[[Boxing]]== '''Events''' * The first of the modern World titles is recognised with [[Jack (Nonpareil) Dempsey]] as the original [[World Middleweight Champion]].<ref>[http://www.cyberboxingzone.com/boxing/middle.htm Cyber Boxing Zone – Lineal Middleweight Champions]. Retrieved on 6 June 2009. [https://www.webcitation.org/5hNmEqTuN?url=http://www.cyberboxingzone.com/boxing/middle.htm Archived] 2009-06-08.</ref> The weight limit for middleweights at this time is 154 pounds. Dempsey will hold the title until 1891. * American heavyweight champion [[John L. Sullivan]] faces a number of challengers but none of them last more than four rounds. Sullivan is very active on the exhibition circuit.<ref name="JLS">[http://www.cyberboxingzone.com/boxing/sully.htm Cyber Boxing Zone – John L Sullivan]. Retrieved on 12 November 2009.</ref> '''Lineal world champions'''<ref>{{cite web|title=Cyber Boxing Zone |url=http://www.cyberboxingzone.com/boxing/pastchp.htm |work= |archiveurl=https://www.webcitation.org/5hg1si20f?url=http://www.cyberboxingzone.com/boxing/pastchp.htm |archivedate=2009-06-20 |deadurl=no |accessdate=2009-06-17 |df= }}</ref> * [[World Middleweight Champion]]ship – [[Jack Nonpareil Dempsey]]
==[[Canadian football]]== '''Events''' * The Canadian Rugby Football Union, forerunner of the [[Canadian Football League]], is established.
==[[Cricket]]== '''Events''' * An [[Australian cricket team in England in 1884|Australian team tours England]] but loses the three-match [[Test cricket|Test series]] 1–0 with two matches drawn. * [[Derbyshire County Cricket Club|Derbyshire]] suffer the ignominy of a [[imperfect season|perfectly bad season]] losing all ten of their county games * In stark contrast [[Nottinghamshire County Cricket Club|Nottinghamshire]] come closer to an absolutely [[perfect season]] than any county side since, winning nine games and being three wickets shy of victory in their tenth '''England''' * [[Champion County]]<ref>A semi-official seasonal title proclaimed by media consensus prior to December 1889 when the official County Championship is constituted.</ref> – [[Nottinghamshire County Cricket Club|Nottinghamshire]] * Most runs – [[George Harris, 4th Baron Harris|Lord Harris]] 1,417 @ 33.73 (HS 112*) * Most wickets – [[Fred Spofforth]] 207 @ 12.82 (BB 8–62) '''Australia''' * Most runs – [[Billy Murdoch]] 567 @ 113.40 (HS 279*) * Most wickets – [[Joey Palmer]] 29 @ 17.51 (BB 6–72)
==[[Gaelic Athletic Association]]== '''Events''' * 1 November — [[Gaelic Athletic Association]] is founded at [[Hayes' Hotel]] in [[Thurles]], [[County Tipperary]], to promote [[hurling]] and [[Gaelic football]]. The foundation date has significance as ''[[Samhain]]'': according to legend the day the [[Fianna]] fell from power.
==[[Golf]]== '''Major tournaments''' * [[1884 Open Championship|British Open]] – [[Jack Simpson]]
==[[Horse racing]]== '''England''' * [[1884 Grand National|Grand National]] – Voluptuary * [[1,000 Guineas Stakes]] – [[Busybody (horse)|Busybody]] * [[2,000 Guineas Stakes]] – [[Scot Free]] * [[Epsom Derby|The Derby]] – dead heat between [[Harvester (horse)|Harvester]] and [[St. Gatien]] * [[Epsom Oaks|The Oaks]] – Busybody * [[St. Leger Stakes]] – [[The Lambkin]] '''Australia''' * [[Melbourne Cup]] – [[Malua (horse)|Malua]] '''Canada''' * [[Queen's Plate]] – Williams '''Ireland''' * [[Irish Grand National]] – The Gift (second successive win) * [[Irish Derby Stakes]] – Theologian '''USA''' * [[1884 Kentucky Derby|Kentucky Derby]] – Buchanan * [[Preakness Stakes]] – Knight of Ellerslie * [[Belmont Stakes]] – Panique
==[[Ice hockey]]== * February 11 – The [[Montreal Victorias]] defeat the [[Ottawa Hockey Club]] 1–0 to win the second [[Montreal Winter Carnival ice hockey tournaments|Montreal Winter Carnival ice hockey tournament]]. * November 28 – The [[Montreal Hockey Club]] is founded.
==[[Rowing (sport)|Rowing]]== '''The Boat Race''' * 7 April — [[Cambridge University Boat Club|Cambridge]] wins the 41st [[The Boat Race|Oxford and Cambridge Boat Race]]
==[[Rugby football]]== '''Home Nations Championship''' * The 2nd series is won by [[England national rugby union team|England]] '''Other events''' * The [[1884 New Zealand rugby union tour of New South Wales]] is the inaugural overseas tour by the New Zealand team
==[[Tennis]]== '''Events''' * Inaugural women's singles championship at [[The Championships, Wimbledon|Wimbledon]] '''England''' * [[The Championships, Wimbledon|Wimbledon Men's Singles Championship]] – [[William Renshaw]] (GB) defeats [[Herbert Lawford]] (GB) 6–0 6–4 9–7 * [[The Championships, Wimbledon|Wimbledon Women's Singles Championship]] – [[Maud Watson]] (GB) defeats [[Lillian Watson (tennis)|Lillian Watson]] (GB) 6–8 6–3 6–3 '''USA''' * [[US Open (tennis)|American Men's Singles Championship]] – [[Richard Sears (tennis)|Richard D. Sears]] (USA) defeats [[Howard A. Taylor]] (USA) 6–0 1–6 6–0 6–2
'''World''' * The 8th [[Open era|pre-open era]] [[1884 Men's Tennis tour|Men's Tennis tour]] gets underway 54 tournaments are staged this year the tour runs from 6 May to 21 December, 1884.
==[[Tobogganing]]== '''Events''' * [[Cresta Run]] constructed at [[St. Moritz]] in Switzerland
==References== {{Reflist}}
{{Sports by year 1851 – 1900}}
[[Category:Sports by year]] [[Category:1884 in sports| ]]

{{Year box}} [[Image:faber.jpg|thumb|350px|right|[[François Faber]] of [[Luxembourg]] won the [[1909 Tour de France]] ]] '''1909 in sports''' describes the year's events in world sport.
==[[American football]]== '''College championship''' * [[NCAA Division I FBS National Football Championship|College football national championship]] – [[Yale Bulldogs football|Yale Bulldogs]]
==[[Association football]]== '''International football''' * [[West Auckland Town F.C.|West Auckland Town]], an English amateur team, defeats [[FC Winterthur]] of Switzerland 2–0 to win the [[Sir Thomas Lipton Trophy]], one of the earliest international club competitions '''Brazil''' * 4 April — [[Sport Club Internacional]] is founded in [[Porto Alegre]] * 12 October - [[Coritiba Foot Ball Club]] is founded in [[Curitiba]] '''England''' * [[The Football League]] – [[Newcastle United]] 53 points, [[Everton FC|Everton]] 46, [[Sunderland FC|Sunderland]] 44, [[Blackburn Rovers]] 41, [[Sheffield Wednesday|The Wednesday]] 40, [[Arsenal FC|Woolwich Arsenal]] 38 * [[1909 FA Cup Final|FA Cup final]] – [[Manchester United F.C.|Manchester United]] 1–0 [[Bristol City]] at [[Crystal Palace National Sports Centre|Crystal Palace]], London '''Germany''' * [[List of German football champions|National Championship]] – [[Phönix Karlsruhe]] 4–2 [[Viktoria Berlin]] at Breslau '''Romania''' * Formation of the [[Romanian Football Federation]] (Federaţia Română de Fotbal or FRF) '''Scotland''' * [[Scottish Football League]] – [[Glasgow Celtic|Celtic]] * [[1908 Scottish Cup Final|Scottish Cup final]] – competition cancelled following a riot at a replay between [[Rangers F.C.|Rangers]] and Celtic; the first match was drawn 2–2 and the replay ended 1–1 '''Spain''' * Formation of the [[Royal Spanish Football Federation]] (Real Federación Española de Fútbol or RFEF). It is originally known as the Federación Española de Clubs de Football.
==[[Athletics (sport)|Athletics]]== * 23 August — [[Tenby Davies|Fred ‘Tenby’ Davies]] (Wales) defeats Bert Day (Ireland) at [[Pontypridd]] to become world champion over the half-mile distance run.
==[[Australian rules football]]== '''VFL Premiership''' * [[Sydney Swans|South Melbourne]] wins the 13th [[Australian Football League|VFL]] Premiership: South Melbourne 4.14 (38) d [[Carlton Football Club|Carlton]] 4.12 (36) at [[Melbourne Cricket Ground]] (MCG)
==[[Bandy]]== '''Sweden''' * [[Allsvenskan and Elitserien (bandy)|Championship final]] – [[AIK Bandy|AIK]] 7–3 [[Djurgårdens IF Bandy|Djurgårdens IF]]
==[[Baseball]]== '''World Series''' * 8–16 October — [[Pittsburgh Pirates]] (NL) defeats [[Detroit Tigers]] (AL) to win the [[1909 World Series]] by 4 games to 3
==[[Boxing]]== '''Events''' * 19 June — [[Monte Attell]] wins the [[World Bantamweight Champion]]ship joining his brother [[Abe Attell]], who holds the [[World Featherweight Champion]]ship, as the first pair of brothers to hold world titles simultaneously. '''Lineal world champions'''<ref>[http://www.cyberboxingzone.com/boxing/pastchp.htm Cyber Boxing Zone]</ref> * [[World Heavyweight Champion]]ship – [[Jack Johnson (boxer)|Jack Johnson]] * [[World Light Heavyweight Champion]]ship – vacant * [[World Middleweight Champion]]ship – [[Stanley Ketchel]] * [[World Welterweight Champion]]ship – vacant * [[World Lightweight Champion]]ship – [[Battling Nelson]] * [[World Featherweight Champion]]ship – [[Abe Attell]] * [[World Bantamweight Champion]]ship – Jimmy Walsh → "Fighting" Jimmy Reagan → [[Monte Attell]]
==[[Canadian football]]== '''Grey Cup''' * 4 December — [[1st Grey Cup]] – [[University of Toronto Varsity Blues]] 26–6 [[Toronto Parkdale Canoe Club]].
==[[Cricket]]== '''Events''' * 15 June — representatives of England, Australia and South Africa meet at [[Lord's]] to form the [[International Cricket Council|Imperial Cricket Conference]] (ICC) '''England''' * [[County Championship]] – [[Kent CCC|Kent]] * [[Minor Counties Championship]] – [[Wiltshire County Cricket Club|Wiltshire]] * Most runs – [[Ernie Hayes]] 2105 @ 36.29 (HS 276) * Most wickets – [[Colin Blythe]] 215 @ 14.54 (BB 9–42) * [[Wisden Cricketers of the Year]] – [[Warren Bardsley]], [[Sydney Barnes]], [[Douglas Carr]], [[Arthur Day (Kent cricketer)|Arthur Day]], [[Vernon Ransford]] '''Australia''' * [[Sheffield Shield]] – [[New South Wales cricket team|New South Wales]] * Most runs – [[Vernon Ransford]] 825 @ 103.12 (HS 182) * Most wickets – [[Jack O'Connor (Australian cricketer)|Jack O'Connor]] 40 @ 23.00 (BB 7–36) '''India''' * [[Bombay Quadrangular|Bombay Triangular]] – [[Europeans cricket team|Europeans]] '''New Zealand''' * [[Plunket Shield]] – [[Auckland cricket team|Auckland]] '''South Africa''' * [[SuperSport Series|Currie Cup]] – [[Western Province cricket team|Western Province]] '''West Indies''' * [[Inter-Colonial Tournament]] – [[Barbados cricket team|Barbados]]
==[[Cycling]]== '''Tour de France''' * [[François Faber]] (Luxembourg) wins the 7th [[1909 Tour de France|Tour de France]] '''Giro d'Italia''' * [[Luigi Ganna]] (Italy) wins the inaugural [[1909 Giro d'Italia|Giro d'Italia]]
==[[Eton Wall Game]]== '''Events''' * 30 November — a goal is scored in the [[St. Andrew's Day]] match at [[Eton College]], the last time this has happened in the St. Andrew's Day game (the most important match of the year) though points have been scored by other methods
==[[Figure skating]]== '''World Figure Skating Championships''' * [[World Figure Skating Championships|World Men's Champion]] – [[Ulrich Salchow]] (Sweden) * [[World Figure Skating Championships|World Women's Champion]] – [[Lily Kronberger]] (Hungary) * [[World Figure Skating Championships|World Pairs Champions]] – [[Phyllis Johnson]] and [[James H. Johnson]] (Great Britain)
==[[Golf]]== '''Major tournaments''' * [[1909 Open Championship|British Open]] – [[John Henry Taylor]] * [[1909 U.S. Open (golf)|U.S. Open]] – [[George Sargent (golfer)|George Sargent]] '''Other tournaments''' * [[The Amateur Championship|British Amateur]] – Robert Maxwell * [[United States Amateur Championship (men's golf)|US Amateur]] – [[Robert A. Gardner (golfer)|Robert A. Gardner]]
==[[Horse racing]]== '''England''' * [[1909 Grand National|Grand National]] – Lutteur III * [[1,000 Guineas Stakes]] – [[Electra (horse)|Electra]] * [[2,000 Guineas Stakes]] – [[Minoru (horse)|Minoru]] * [[Epsom Derby|The Derby]] – Minoru * [[Epsom Oaks|The Oaks]] – [[Perola (horse)|Perola]] * [[St. Leger Stakes]] – [[Bayardo (horse)|Bayardo]] '''Australia''' * [[Melbourne Cup]] – Prince Foote '''Canada''' * [[Queen's Plate]] – Shimonese '''Ireland''' * [[Irish Grand National]] – Little Hack II * [[Irish Derby Stakes]] – [[Bachelor's Double]] '''USA''' * [[1909 Kentucky Derby|Kentucky Derby]] – Wintergreen * [[Preakness Stakes]] – Effendi * [[Belmont Stakes]] – Joe Madden
==[[Ice hockey]]== '''Stanley Cup''' * March — [[Ottawa Hockey Club]] wins the [[Eastern Canada Amateur Hockey Association|Eastern Canada Hockey Association]] (ECHA) championship and the [[Stanley Cup]]. * March — [[Renfrew Creamery Kings]] win the [[Federal Amateur Hockey League|Federal Hockey League]] championship and challenge for the Stanley Cup, but cannot play because the Stanley Cup trustees rule their players are ineligible. '''Amateur hockey''' * February — the [[1909 Allan Cup|Allan Cup]] is donated to be the amateur championship hockey trophy of Canada * March — [[Ottawa Cliffsides]] win the [[Inter-Provincial Amateur Hockey Union]] (IPAHU) and the Allan Cup. The Cliffsides then lose a challenge to [[Queen's Golden Gaels|Queen's College]] of [[Kingston, Ontario]]. '''Professional hockey''' * 25 November — Eastern Canada Hockey Association (ECHA) disbands over the plans of the [[Montreal Wanderers]] to change rinks. The Wanderers are shut out and the new Canadian Hockey Association (CHA) is formed with the remainder of the ECHA teams. The CHA will disband in January 1910. * 2 December — The Montreal Wanderers form the [[National Hockey Association]] (NHA) with the [[Renfrew Creamery Kings]], [[Cobalt Silver Kings]] and [[Haileybury Comets]] of the Temiscaming league. The NHA owners also organize a new team ''Les Canadiens'' which is the basis of today's [[Montreal Canadiens]]. The NHA will absorb Ottawa and the Montreal Shamrocks of the CHA in January 1910.
==[[Motorsport]]== {{main|1909 in motorsport}}
==[[Rowing (sport)|Rowing]]== '''The Boat Race''' * 3 April — [[Oxford University Boat Club|Oxford]] wins the 66th [[The Boat Race 1909|Oxford and Cambridge Boat Race]]
==[[Rugby league]]== '''International''' * 10 February — [[Great Britain national rugby league team|Great Britain]] defeats [[Australian Kangaroos|Australia]] to claim the first ever Ashes series in the final match of the [[1908–09 Kangaroo tour of Great Britain]] '''England''' * [[Rugby Football League Championship|Championship]] – [[Wigan Warriors|Wigan]] * [[Challenge Cup|Challenge Cup final]] – [[Wakefield Trinity]] 17–0 [[Hull F.C.]] at [[Headingley Rugby Stadium]], [[Leeds]] * [[Rugby league county leagues|Lancashire League Championship]] – [[Wigan Warriors|Wigan]] * [[Rugby league county leagues|Yorkshire League Championship]] – [[Halifax R.L.F.C.|Halifax]] * [[RFL Lancashire Cup|Lancashire]] [[Rugby league county cups|County Cup]] – [[Wigan Warriors|Wigan]] 10–9 [[Oldham R.L.F.C.|Oldham]] * [[RFL Yorkshire Cup|Yorkshire]] [[Rugby league county cups|County Cup]] – [[Halifax R.L.F.C.|Halifax]] 9–5 [[Hunslet R.L.F.C.|Hunslet]] '''Australia''' * 14 September — [[New South Wales Rugby League premiership|NSW Premiership]] is won by minor premiers [[South Sydney Rabbitohs|South Sydney]] on a forfeit after [[Balmain Tigers|Balmain]] withdraws from the grand final
==[[Rugby union]]== '''Home Nations Championship''' * 27th [[1909 Home Nations Championship|Home Nations Championship]] series is won by [[Wales national rugby union team|Wales]] * Wales defeats [[France national rugby union team|France]] in a 1909 non-championship match. It is later retrospectively regarded as a [[Grand Slam (rugby union)|Grand Slam]] winner. * October 8 – The first [[rugby football]] match to be played at [[Twickenham Stadium]] is won by the Harlequins when they defeat Richmond at the brand new ground.
==[[Speed skating]]== '''Speed Skating World Championships''' * [[1909 World Allround Speed Skating Championships|Men's All-round Champion]] – [[Oscar Mathisen]] (Norway)
==[[Tennis]]== '''Australia''' * [[List of Australian Open Men's Singles champions|Australian Men's Singles Championship]] – [[Anthony Wilding]] (NZ) defeats [[Ernie Parker]] (Australia) 6–1 7–5 6–2 '''England''' * [[The Championships, Wimbledon|Wimbledon Men's Singles Championship]] – [[Arthur Gore (tennis)|Arthur Gore]] (GB) defeats [[Josiah Ritchie]] (GB) 6–8 1–6 6–2 6–2 6–2 * [[The Championships, Wimbledon|Wimbledon Women's Singles Championship]] – [[Dora Boothby]] defeats [[Agnes Morton]] 6–4 4–6 8–6 '''France''' * [[List of French Open Men's Singles champions and finalists|French Men's Singles Championship]] – [[Max Decugis]] defeats [[Maurice Germot]]: details unknown * [[List of French Open Women's Singles champions|French Women's Singles Championship]] – [[Jeanne Matthey]] defeats Gallay: details unknown '''USA''' * [[US Open (tennis)|American Men's Singles Championship]] – [[William Larned]] defeats [[William Clothier]] 6–1 6–2 5–7 1–6 6–1 * [[US Open (tennis)|American Women's Singles Championship]] – [[Hazel Hotchkiss Wightman]] defeats [[Maud Barger-Wallach]] 6–0 6–1 '''Davis Cup''' * [[1909 International Lawn Tennis Challenge]] – {{davis|Australasia}} 5–0 {{davis|USA|1908}} at Double Bay Grounds (grass) [[Sydney]], [[Australia]]
==References== {{Reflist}}
{{Sports by year 1901 – 1950}}
{{DEFAULTSORT:1909 In Sports}} [[Category:Sports by year]] [[Category:1909 in sports| ]]

{{Year box}} '''1921 in sports''' describes the year’s events in world sport. ==[[American football]]== * [[1921 Chicago Staleys season|Chicago Staleys]] (later the Chicago Bears) win the 1921 [[American Professional Football Association]] title, albeit [[Staley Swindle|not without dispute]]. The APFA will eventually become the [[National Football League]]. * [[Rose Bowl Game|Rose Bowl]] (1920 season): ** The [[California Golden Bears]] won 21-0 over the [[Ohio State Buckeyes]] to win the college football national championship * [[Cornell Big Red]] – [[college football]] national championship * 8 October — the first radio broadcast of a college game takes place between [[1921 West Virginia vs. Pittsburgh football game|West Virginia and Pittsburgh]] ==[[Association football]]== '''Brazil''' *[[Cruzeiro Esporte Clube|Cruzeiro of Belo Horizonte]], officially founded on January 2.{{citation needed|date=January 2016}} '''England''' * [[1920–21 Football League|The Football League]] – [[Burnley F.C.|Burnley]] 59 points, [[Manchester City F.C.|Manchester City]] 54, [[Bolton Wanderers F.C.|Bolton Wanderers]] 52, [[Liverpool F.C.|Liverpool]] 51, [[Newcastle United F.C.|Newcastle United]] 50, [[Tottenham Hotspur F.C.|Tottenham Hotspur]] 47 * [[1921 FA Cup Final|FA Cup final]] – [[Tottenham Hotspur]] 1–0 [[Wolverhampton Wanderers]] at [[Stamford Bridge (stadium)|Stamford Bridge]], London * The Football League is expanded by the conversion of the [[Football League Third Division|Third Division]] (founded in 1920) into the [[Football League Third Division South|Third Division South]] (D3S: 22 clubs) and the creation of the [[Football League Third Division North|Third Division North]] (D3N: 20 clubs). This brings the total number of League clubs to 86. Existing league clubs in D3N are [[Stockport County F.C.|Stockport County]] (relegated from the [[Football League Second Division|Second Division]]) and [[Grimsby Town F.C.|Grimsby Town]] (transferred from the former Third Division). New league members in D3N are: [[Accrington Stanley F.C. (1891)|Accrington Stanley]] (1921–1961), [[Ashington A.F.C.|Ashington]] (1921–1929), [[Barrow A.F.C.|Barrow]] (1921–1972), [[Chesterfield F.C.|Chesterfield]], [[Crewe Alexandra F.C.|Crewe Alexandra]], [[Darlington F.C.|Darlington]], [[Durham City F.C.|Durham City]] (1921–1928), [[Halifax Town A.F.C.|Halifax Town]], [[Hartlepool United F.C.|Hartlepool United]], [[Lincoln City F.C.|Lincoln City]], [[Nelson F.C.|Nelson]] (1921–1931), [[Rochdale A.F.C.|Rochdale]], [[Southport F.C.|Southport]] (1921–1978), [[Stalybridge Celtic F.C.|Stalybridge Celtic]] (1921–1923), [[Tranmere Rovers F.C.|Tranmere Rovers]], [[Walsall F.C.|Walsall]], [[Wigan Borough F.C.|Wigan Borough]] (1921–1931) and [[Wrexham A.F.C.|Wrexham]]. * Apart from Grimsby Town (now in D3N) and [[Crystal Palace F.C.|Crystal Palace]] (promoted to the Second Division), all the remaining members of the former Third Division are transferred to D3S. Two new clubs are elected to this division: [[Aberdare Athletic F.C.|Aberdare Athletic]] (1921–1927) and [[Charlton Athletic F.C.|Charlton Athletic]]. '''Germany''' * [[List of German football champions|National Championship]] – [[FC Nuremberg]] 5–0 [[Berliner FC Vorwärts 1890]] at Düsseldorf '''Republic of Ireland''' * Formation of the [[Football Association of Ireland]] (FAI). It applies solely to the Republic of Ireland and is not to be confused with the [[Irish Football Association]] (IFA), which is now the organising body for football in Northern Ireland only. The split in Irish football governance is not reflected in other sports such as [[cricket]] and [[rugby union]], in which [[Cricket Ireland]] and the [[Irish Rugby Football Union]] administer both countries. ==[[Track and field athletics|Athletics]]== '''Men's 100 metres''' * [[Charlie Paddock]] (USA) breaks the world record by running a time of 10.4 at [[Redlands, California]]. '''Lithuania''' * Officially established [[Lithuanian Athletics Championships]]. '''Monaco''' * [[1921 Women's World Games|first Women’s Olympiad]] in Monte Carlo ==[[Australian rules football]]== * 30 June – [[North Melbourne Football Club|North Melbourne]] disbands in an attempt to merge with VFL club [[Essendon Football Club|Essendon]] and is disqualified from the rest of [[1921 VFA season|the VFA season]]; the merger is precluded by a veto by the government of Essendon moving to [[Arden Street Oval|Arden Street]]. '''[[1921 VFL season|VFL Premiership]]''' * [[Richmond Football Club|Richmond]] wins the 25th [[Australian Football League|VFL]] Premiership, defeating [[Carlton Football Club|Carlton]] 5.6 (36) to 4.8 (32) [[1921 VFL Grand Final|in the Grand Final]] '''[[South Australian National Football League|South Australian Football League]]''' * 7 May – [[Glenelg Football Club|Glenelg]] become the SAFL’s eighth club when they play their first match against [[West Adelaide Football Club|West Adelaide]], losing 6.5 (41) to 18.10 (118). * 8 October – [[Port Adelaide Football Club (SANFL)|Port Adelaide]] 4.8 (32) defeat [[Norwood Football Club|Norwood]] 3.6 (24) for their ninth SAFL premiership. * [[Magarey Medal]] won by [[Dan Moriarty (Australian rules footballer born 1895)|Dan Moriarty]] (South Adelaide), [[Charlie Adams (Australian footballer)|Charlie Adams]]{{ref label|restropective1|a|a}} (Port Adelaide), [[John Karney]]{{ref label|restropective1|a|a}} (West Torrens) and [[Walter Scott (Australian footballer)|Walter Scott]]{{ref label|restropective1|a|a}} (Norwood) '''West Australian Football League''' * 1 October – [[East Perth Football Club|East Perth]] 5.9 (39) defeats [[East Fremantle Football Club|East Fremantle]] 4.8 (32) to win its third consecutive premiership. * The inaugural [[Sandover Medal]] is won by [[Tom Outridge, Sr.]] ([[Subiaco Football Club|Subiaco]]), and posthumously awarded retrospectively{{ref label|restropective2|b|b}} to [[Cyril Hoft]] ([[Perth Football Club|Perth]]). ==[[Bandy]]== '''Sweden''' * [[Swedish bandy champions|Championship final]] – [[IK Sirius]] 5–2 [[IFK Uppsala Bandy|IFK Uppsala]] (replay following 2–2 draw) ==[[Baseball]]== '''World Series''' * 5–13 October — [[1921 New York Giants season|New York Giants]] (NL) defeats [[1921 New York Yankees season|New York Yankees]] (AL) to win the [[1921 World Series]] by 5 games to 3 '''Major League Baseball''' * [[Babe Ruth]] hits 59 [[home run]]s for the [[1921 New York Yankees season|New York Yankees]], establishing a new single-season record for the third consecutive year '''Negro League Baseball''' * The [[Chicago American Giants]] win their second consecutive [[Negro National League (the first)|Negro National League]] pennant ==[[Boxing]]== '''Events''' * 2 July — boxing’s first “million dollar gate” occurs when [[Jack Dempsey]] meets [[Georges Carpentier]] in a “hastily assembled outdoor arena built on a farm in [[Jersey City]], [[New Jersey]]”. A crowd of more than 80,000 attends an event billed by its promoter [[Tex Rickard]] as the "Battle of the Century". Dempsey wins by a fourth round knockout in a scheduled 12-round fight which is also special for its radio broadcast. It is the first-ever broadcast to a "mass audience" with ringside commentary relayed over the new [[radiophone]] to hundreds of thousands of people in the northeastern United States.[http://www.pophistorydig.com/?p=581 The Pop History Dig – Dempsey v. Carpentier]. Retrieved on 28 November 2009. * [[Pete Herman|Pete “Kid” Herman]] regains the [[World Bantamweight Champion]]ship but is beaten soon afterwards by new champion [[Johnny Buff]]. '''Lineal world champions'''[http://www.cyberboxingzone.com/boxing/pastchp.htm Cyber Boxing Zone] * [[World Heavyweight Champion]]ship – [[Jack Dempsey]] * [[World Light Heavyweight Champion]]ship – [[Georges Carpentier]] * [[World Middleweight Champion]]ship – [[Johnny Wilson (boxer)|Johnny Wilson]] * [[World Welterweight Champion]]ship – [[Jack Britton]] * [[World Lightweight Champion]]ship – [[Benny Leonard]] * [[World Featherweight Champion]]ship – [[Johnny Kilbane]] * [[World Bantamweight Champion]]ship – [[Joe Lynch (boxer)|Joe Lynch]] → [[Pete Herman|Pete "Kid" Herman]] → [[Johnny Buff]] * [[World Flyweight Champion]]ship – [[Jimmy Wilde]] ==[[Canadian football]]== '''Grey Cup''' * [[9th Grey Cup]] in the [[Canadian Football League]] – [[Toronto Argonauts]] 23–0 [[Edmonton Eskimos]] ==[[Cricket]]== '''Events''' * [[England national cricket team|England]] tours Australia and becomes the first team to lose every match in a five-match [[Test cricket|Test series]]. In the [[1921 English cricket season|1921 English season]], [[Australia national cricket team|Australia]] emphasises the post-war superiority that it owes, in particular, to the pace duo of [[Jack Gregory (cricketer)|Jack Gregory]] and [[Ted McDonald]]. Having won 5–0 in Australia the previous winter, the Australians win the first three Tests of the 1921 tour and then draw the last two. '''England''' * [[County Championship]] – [[Middlesex County Cricket Club|Middlesex]] * [[Minor Counties Championship]] – [[Staffordshire County Cricket Club|Staffordshire]] * Most runs – [[Phil Mead]] 3179 @ 69.10 (HS 280*) * Most wickets – [[Alec Kennedy]] 186 @ 21.55 (BB 8–11) * [[Wisden Cricketers of the Year]] – [[Hubert Ashton]], [[Jack Bryan]], [[Jack Gregory (cricketer)|Jack Gregory]], [[Charlie Macartney]], [[Ted McDonald]] '''Australia''' * [[Sheffield Shield]] – [[New South Wales cricket team|New South Wales]] * Most runs – [[Patsy Hendren]] 1178 @ 62.00 (HS 271) * Most wickets – [[Arthur Mailey]] 81 @ 22.53 (BB 9–121) '''India''' * [[Bombay Quadrangular]] – [[Hindus cricket team|Hindus]] and [[Parsees cricket team|Parsees]] (shared) '''New Zealand''' * [[Plunket Shield]] – [[Wellington cricket team|Wellington]] '''South Africa''' * [[SuperSport Series|Currie Cup]] – [[Western Province cricket team|Western Province]] '''West Indies''' * [[Inter-Colonial Tournament]] – unfinished ==[[Cycling]]== '''Tour de France''' * [[Léon Scieur]] (Belgium) wins the 15th [[1921 Tour de France|Tour de France]] '''Giro d'Italia''' * [[Giovanni Brunero]] of Legnano wins the ninth [[1921 Giro d'Italia|Giro d'Italia]] ==[[Figure skating]]== '''World Figure Skating Championships''' * The championships are not held in 1921 ==[[Golf]]== '''Major tournaments''' * [[1921 Open Championship|British Open]] – [[Jock Hutchison]] * [[1921 U.S. Open (golf)|US Open]] – [[Jim Barnes]] * [[1921 PGA Championship|USPGA Championship]] – [[Walter Hagen]] '''Other tournaments''' * [[The Amateur Championship|British Amateur]] – [[Willie Hunter (golfer)|Willie Hunter]] * [[United States Amateur Championship (men's golf)|US Amateur]] – [[Jesse P. Guilford]] ==[[Horse racing]]== '''England''' * [[1921 Grand National|Grand National]] – Shaun Spadah * [[1,000 Guineas Stakes]] – [[Bettina (horse)|Bettina]] * [[2,000 Guineas Stakes]] – [[Craig an Eran]] * [[Epsom Derby|The Derby]] – [[Humorist (horse)|Humorist]] * [[Epsom Oaks|The Oaks]] – [[Love in Idleness (horse)|Love in Idleness]] * [[St. Leger Stakes]] – [[Polemarch (horse)|Polemarch]] '''Australia''' * [[Melbourne Cup]] – Sister Olive '''Canada''' * [[Queen's Plate]] – Herendesy '''France''' * [[Prix de l'Arc de Triomphe]] – [[Ksar (horse)|Ksar]] '''Ireland''' * [[Irish Grand National]] – Bohernore * [[Irish Derby Stakes]] – Ballyheron '''USA''' * [[1921 Kentucky Derby|Kentucky Derby]] – Behave Yourself * [[Preakness Stakes]] – Broomspun * [[Belmont Stakes]] – Grey Lag ==[[Ice hockey]]== '''Stanley Cup''' * [[Ottawa Senators (original)|Ottawa Senators]] defeats [[1920–21 Toronto St. Patricks season|Toronto St. Patricks]] to win the [[National Hockey League|NHL]] championship. * [[Vancouver Millionaires]] defeats [[Seattle Metropolitans]] in a two–game total–goal series 1–3, 6–0 (7–3) to win the [[Pacific Coast Hockey Association|PCHA]] championship. * 21 March – 4 April — Ottawa Senators defeats Vancouver Millionaires in the [[1921 Stanley Cup Finals]] by 3 games to 2 ==[[Motorsport]]== {{main|1921 in motorsport|List of 1921 motorsport champions}} ==[[Multi-sport event]]s== '''Far Eastern Championship Games''' * Fifth [[1921 Far Eastern Championship Games|Far Eastern Championship Games]] held in [[Shanghai]]. '''Women's World Games''' * The [[1921 Women's Olympiad]] begins in Monte Carlo, first international [[women's sports]] event ==[[Rowing (sport)|Rowing]]== '''The Boat Race''' * 30 March — [[Cambridge University Boat Club|Cambridge]] wins the 73rd [[The Boat Race|Oxford and Cambridge Boat Race]] ==[[Rugby league]]== '''England''' * [[Rugby Football League Championship|Championship]] – [[Hull F.C.|Hull]] * [[Challenge Cup|Challenge Cup final]] – [[Leigh Centurions|Leigh]] 13–0 [[Halifax R.L.F.C.|Halifax]] at [[Wheater's Field]], [[Broughton, Salford|Broughton]] * [[Rugby league county leagues|Lancashire League Championship]] – [[Wigan Warriors|Wigan]] * [[Rugby league county leagues|Yorkshire League Championship]] – [[Halifax R.L.F.C.|Halifax]] * [[RFL Lancashire Cup|Lancashire]] Five Nations Championship|Five Nations Championship]] series is won by [[England national rugby union team|England]] who complete the [[Grand Slam (rugby union)|Grand Slam]] ==[[Shooting {{Year box}} '''1924 in sports''' describes the year's events in world sport.
==[[American football]]== * [[History of National Football League Championship|NFL Championship]] – [[Cleveland Bulldogs]] *[[Anthracite League|Anthracite League champions]] – [[Pottsville Maroons]]
==[[Association football]]== '''England''' * [[The Football League]] – [[Huddersfield Town]] 57 points, [[Cardiff City]] 57, [[Sunderland A.F.C.|Sunderland]] 53, [[Bolton Wanderers]] 50, [[Sheffield United F.C.|Sheffield United]] 50, [[Aston Villa]] 49 * [[1924 FA Cup Final|FA Cup final]] – [[Newcastle United]] 2–0 [[Aston Villa]] at [[Wembley Stadium (1924)|Empire Stadium, Wembley, London]] '''Germany''' * [[List of German football champions|National Championship]] – [[1. FC Nürnberg]] 2–0 [[Hamburger SV]] at Berlin '''Greece''' * [[AEK Athens]] officially founded on April 13.{{citation needed|date=December 2016}} '''Monaco''' * [[AS Monaco FC|AS Monaco]] officially founded on August 23.{{citation needed|date=December 2016}}
==[[Track and field athletics|Athletics]]== '''Men's 1500 metres''' * [[Paavo Nurmi]] (Finland) breaks the world record by running a time of 3:52.6 at [[Helsinki]].
'''England''' * [[1924 Women's Olympiad]], [[Stamford Bridge (stadium)|Stamford Bridge]], London
==[[Australian rules football]]== '''VFL Premiership''' * [[Essendon Football Club|Essendon]] wins the 28th [[Australian Football League|VFL]] Premiership: under the finals system used, no Grand Final is played. '''Brownlow Medal''' * The inaugural [[Brownlow Medal]] is awarded to [[Edward Greeves]] of [[Geelong Football Club|Geelong]].
==[[Bandy]]== '''Sweden''' * [[Swedish bandy champions|Championship final]] – [[Västerås SK Bandy|Västerås SK]] 4–1 [[IF Linnéa]]
==[[Baseball]]== '''World Series''' * 4–10 October — [[Washington Senators (1901–60)|Washington Senators]] (AL) defeats [[New York Giants (NL)|New York Giants]] (NL) to win the [[1924 World Series]] by 4 games to 3 '''Negro League Baseball''' * [[Kansas City Monarchs]] ([[Negro National League (1920–1931)|NNL]]) defeats [[Hilldale Club|Hilldale]] ([[Eastern Colored League|ECL]]) 5 games to 4 with 1 tie in the first official [[1924 Colored World Series|Negro League World Series]]. * Pitcher [[Nip Winters]] wins a record 27 games for [[Hilldale Club|Hilldale]] in the ECL regular season.
==[[Biathlon]]== '''1924 Winter Olympics''' * [[Military patrol]], the forerunner of [[biathlon]] which combines [[cross-country skiing]] and [[shooting sports|rifle shooting]], is staged as a demonstration event at the inaugural [[Winter Olympics]] in [[Chamonix]]. The winning team is Switzerland.
==[[Bobsleigh]]== '''1924 Winter Olympics''' * Bobsleigh debuts oaiusfhkuhoidsfuhoiuhin [[Chamonix]] at the inaugural [[Winter Olympics]]. The sole event is the 4-man bob which is won by Switzerland I (gold) ahead of Great Britain II (silver) and Belgium I (bronze).
==[[Boxing]]== '''Events''' * 10 August — the [[World Featherweight Champion]]ship title becomes vacant as [[Johnny Dundee]] relinquishes it to fight as a lightweight '''Lineal world champions'''<ref>[http://www.cyberboxingzone.com/boxing/pastchp.htm Cyber Boxing Zone]</ref> * [[World Heavyweight Champion]]ship – [[Jack Dempsey]] * [[World Light Heavyweight Champion]]ship – [[Mike McTigue]] * [[World Middleweight Champion]]ship – [[Harry Greb]] * [[World Welterweight Champion]]ship – [[Mickey Walker (boxer)|Mickey Walker]] * [[World Lightweight Champion]]ship – [[Benny Leonard]] * [[World Featherweight Champion]]ship – [[Johnny Dundee]] → vacant * [[World Bantamweight Champion]]ship – [[Joe Lynch (boxer)|Joe Lynch]] → [[Abe Goldstein]] → Eddie "Cannonball" Martin * [[World Flyweight Champion]]ship – [[Francisco Guilledo|Pancho Villa]]
==[[Canadian football]]== '''Grey Cup''' * [[12th Grey Cup]] in the [[Canadian Football League]] – Queen's University 11–2 [[Toronto Balmy Beach Beachers|Toronto Balmy Beach]]
==[[Cricket]]== '''Events''' * [[England national cricket team|England]] defeats [[South Africa national cricket team|South Africa]] 3–0 with two matches drawn. There is a sensational start to the series when the South Africans are bowled out for only 30, in just 12.3 overs, in their first innings of the First Test at [[Edgbaston Cricket Ground|Edgbaston]], England having made over 400. '''England''' * [[County Championship]] – [[Yorkshire County Cricket Club|Yorkshire]] * [[Minor Counties Championship]] – [[Berkshire County Cricket Club|Berkshire]] * Most runs – [[Frank Woolley]] 2344 @ 49.87 (HS 202) * Most wickets – [[Maurice Tate]] 205 @ 13.74 (BB 8–18) * [[Wisden Cricketers of the Year]] – [[Bob Catterall]], [[Jack MacBryan]], [[Herbie Taylor]], [[Dick Tyldesley]], [[Dodger Whysall]] '''Australia''' * [[Sheffield Shield]] – [[Victoria cricket team|Victoria]] * Most runs – [[Bill Ponsford]] 777 @ 111.00 (HS 248) * Most wickets – [[Albert Hartkopf]] and [[Norman Williams (Australian cricketer)|Norman Williams]] 26 apiece '''India''' * [[Bombay Quadrangular]] – [[Hindus cricket team|Hindus]] '''New Zealand''' * [[Plunket Shield]] – [[Wellington cricket team|Wellington]] '''South Africa''' * [[SuperSport Series|Currie Cup]] – [[Transvaal cricket team|Transvaal]] '''West Indies''' * [[Inter-Colonial Tournament]] – [[Barbados cricket team|Barbados]]
==[[Curling]]== '''1924 Winter Olympics''' * Curling is played at the inaugural [[1924 Winter Olympics|Winter Olympics]]. It is a demonstration sport at the time but is retrospectively granted official status. The gold medal is won by the Great Britain and Ireland team.
==[[Cycling]]== '''Tour de France''' * [[Ottavio Bottecchia]] (Italy) wins the 18th [[1924 Tour de France|Tour de France]]
==[[Field hockey]]== '''Events''' * 7 January — the [[International Hockey Federation]] (FIH) is founded in Paris by seven member countries: Austria, Belgium, Czechoslovakia, France, Hungary, Spain and Switzerland.
==[[Figure skating]]== '''Events''' * Figure skating is included in the inaugural [[1924 Winter Olympics|Winter Olympics]], having already featured in the [[1908 Summer Olympics|1908]] and [[1920 Summer Olympics]]. The Olympic gold medallists and the world championship winners are the same in all three events. '''1924 Winter Olympics''' * Men's individual – [[Gillis Grafström]] (Sweden) * Women's individual – [[Herma Szabo]] (Austria) * Pairs – Helene Engelmann and Alfred Berger (Austria) '''World Figure Skating Championships''' * [[World Figure Skating Championships|World Men's Champion]] – [[Gillis Grafström]] (Sweden) * [[World Figure Skating Championships|World Women's Champion]] – [[Herma Szabo]] (Austria) * [[World Figure Skating Championships|World Pairs Champions]] – Helene Engelmann and Alfred Berger (Austria)
==[[Golf]]== '''Major tournaments''' * [[1924 Open Championship|British Open]] – [[Walter Hagen]] * [[1924 U.S. Open (golf)|US Open]] – [[Cyril Walker]] * [[1924 PGA Championship|USPGA Championship]] – [[Walter Hagen]] '''Other tournaments''' * [[The Amateur Championship|British Amateur]] – [[Ernest Holderness]] * [[United States Amateur Championship (men's golf)|US Amateur]] – [[Bobby Jones (golfer)|Bobby Jones]]
==[[Horse racing]]== '''Events''' * The inaugural running of the [[Cheltenham Gold Cup]] is won by Red Splash '''England''' * [[Cheltenham Gold Cup]] – [[Red Splash]] * [[1924 Grand National|Grand National]] – Master Robert * [[1,000 Guineas Stakes]] – [[Plack (horse)|Plack]] * [[2,000 Guineas Stakes]] – [[Diophon]] * [[Epsom Derby|The Derby]] – [[Sansovino (horse)|Sansovino]] * [[Epsom Oaks|The Oaks]] – [[Straitlace]] * [[St. Leger Stakes]] – [[Salmon-Trout]] '''Australia''' * [[Melbourne Cup]] – Backwood '''Canada''' * [[Queen's Plate]] – Maternal Pride '''France''' * [[Prix de l'Arc de Triomphe]] – Massine '''Ireland''' * [[Irish Grand National]] – Kilbarry * [[Irish Derby Stakes]] – Haine ''dead heated with'' Zodiac '''USA''' * [[1924 Kentucky Derby|Kentucky Derby]] – Black Gold * [[Preakness Stakes]] – Nellie Morse * [[Belmont Stakes]] – Mad Play
==[[Ice hockey]]== '''Events''' * Ice hockey is included in the inaugural [[1924 Winter Olympics|Winter Olympics]], having already featured in the [[1920 Summer Olympics]]. Canada successfully defends the Olympic title. '''1924 Winter Olympics''' * Gold Medal – Canada * Silver Medal – USA * Bronze Medal – Great Britain '''Stanley Cup''' * 22–25 March — [[Montreal Canadiens]] defeats [[Calgary Tigers]] by 2 games to 0 in the [[1924 Stanley Cup Finals]] '''Events''' * [[Sault Ste. Marie Greyhounds]] defeats the [[Winnipeg Selkirks]] 6–3 to win the [[Allan Cup]] * 1 December — the expansion [[Boston Bruins]] and [[Montreal Maroons]] of the NHL play their inaugural game against each other at Boston. Boston wins this game 2–1 but then lose eleven in a row.
==[[Motorsport]]== {{main|1924 in motorsport|List of 1924 motorsport champions}}
==[[Nordic skiing]]== '''Events''' * Nordic skiing stages its first international competitions at the inaugural Winter Olympics in [[Chamonix]]. Four events are held (for men only): [[cross-country skiing]] over 18 km and 50 km; [[ski jumping]] on the large hill; and [[Nordic combined]] as an individual event. '''1924 Winter Olympics''' * [[Cross-country skiing]] (18 km) – gold medal: [[Thorleif Haug]] (Norway) * Cross-country skiing (50 km) – gold medal: [[Thorleif Haug]] (Norway) * [[Ski jumping]] – gold medal: [[Jacob Tullin Thams]] (Norway) * [[Nordic combined]] – gold medal: [[Thorleif Haug]] (Norway)
==[[Olympic Games]]== '''1924 Winter Olympics''' * The [[1924 Winter Olympics]], the inaugural [[Winter Olympics]], takes place in [[Chamonix]], France. It is originally called ''Semaine des Sports d'Hiver'', or "International Winter Sports Week". * Norway wins the most medals (18) and the most gold medals (5) '''1924 Summer Olympics''' * The [[1924 Summer Olympics]] takes place in Paris * United States wins the most medals (99) and the most gold medals (45)
==[[Rowing (sport)|Rowing]]== '''The Boat Race''' * 5 April — [[Cambridge University Boat Club|Cambridge]] wins the 76th [[The Boat Race|Oxford and Cambridge Boat Race]]
==[[Rugby league]]== '''England''' * [[Rugby Football League Championship|Championship]] – [[Batley Bulldogs|Batley]] * [[Challenge Cup|Challenge Cup final]] – [[Wigan Warriors|Wigan]] 21–4 [[Oldham R.L.F.C.|Oldham]] at [[Athletic Grounds, Rochdale]] * [[Rugby league county leagues|Lancashire League Championship]] – [[Wigan Warriors|Wigan]] * [[Rugby league county leagues|Yorkshire League Championship]] – [[Batley Bulldogs|Batley]] * [[RFL Lancashire Cup|Lancashire]] [[Rugby league county cups|County Cup]] – [[St Helens Recreation RLFC|St Helens Recs]] 17–0 [[Swinton Lions|Swinton]] * [[RFL Yorkshire Cup|Yorkshire]] [[Rugby league county cups|County Cup]] – [[Hull F.C.]] 10–4 [[Huddersfield Giants|Huddersfield]] '''Australia''' * [[New South Wales Rugby League premiership|NSW Premiership]] – [[Balmain Tigers|Balmain]] 3–0 [[South Sydney Rabbitohs|South Sydney]] (grand final)
==[[Rugby union]]== '''Five Nations Championship''' * 37th [[1924 Five Nations Championship|Five Nations Championship]] series is won by [[England national rugby union team|England]] who complete the [[Grand Slam (rugby union)|Grand Slam]]
==[[Speed skating]]== '''Events''' * Speed skating debuts as an Olympic sport in [[Chamonix]] at the inaugural [[Winter Olympics]]. Five men only events are held. '''Speed Skating World Championships''' * [[World Allround Speed Skating Championships for Men|Men's All-round Champion]] – [[Roald Larsen]] (Norway) '''1924 Winter Olympics''' * 500m – gold medal: [[Charles Jewtraw]] (USA) * 1500m – gold medal: [[Clas Thunberg]] (Finland) * 5000m – gold medal: [[Clas Thunberg]] (Finland) * 10000m – gold medal: [[Julius Skutnabb]] (Finland) * All-round – gold medal: [[Clas Thunberg]] (Finland)
==[[Tennis]]== '''Australia''' * [[List of Australian Open Men's Singles champions|Australian Men's Singles Championship]] – [[James Anderson (tennis)|James Anderson]] (Australia) defeats [[Richard Schlesinger (tennis)|Richard Schlesinger]] (Australia) 6–3 6–4 3–6 5–7 6–3 * [[List of Australian Open Women's Singles champions|Australian Women's Singles Championship]] – [[Sylvia Lance Harper]] (Australia) defeats [[Esna Boyd Robertson]] (Australia) 6–3 3–6 8–6 '''England''' * [[The Championships Wimbledon|Wimbledon Men's Singles Championship]] – [[Jean Borotra]] (France) defeats [[René Lacoste]] (France) 6–1 3–6 6–1 3–6 6–4 * [[The Championships Wimbledon|Wimbledon Women's Singles Championship]] – [[Kitty McKane Godfree]] (Great Britain) defeats [[Helen Wills Moody]] (USA) 4–6 6–4 6–4 '''France''' * [[List of French Open Men's Singles champions and finalists|French Men's Singles Championship]] – [[Jean Borotra]] (France) defeats [[René Lacoste]] (France) 7–5 6–4 0–6 5–7 6–2 * [[List of French Open Women's Singles champions|French Women's Singles Championship]] – [[Emilienne Didi Vlasto]] (France) defeats [[Jeanne Vaussard]] (France) 6–2 6–3 '''USA''' * [[List of US Open Men's Singles champions|American Men's Singles Championship]] – [[Bill Tilden]] (USA) defeats [[Bill Johnston (tennis)|Bill Johnston]] (USA) 6–1 9–7 6–2 * [[List of US Open Women's Singles champions|American Women's Singles Championship]] – [[Helen Wills Moody]] (USA) defeats [[Molla Bjurstedt Mallory]] (Norway) 6–1 6–3 '''Davis Cup''' * [[1924 International Lawn Tennis Challenge]] – {{davis|USA|1912}} 5–0 {{davis|AUS}} at [[Germantown Cricket Club]] (grass) [[Philadelphia]], United States
==References== {{Reflist}}
