[[Category:Disabled sports| ]] [[Category:Sports by type]]

In sports, a '''drought''' refers to instances in which an individual or team has gone through a lengthy period of time without accomplishing some goal. For a team, this usually refers to an extended period of time without making the [[playoff]]s or winning a championship. Droughts occur for a variety of reasons, from chronic mismanagement to bad luck. Some droughts are also popularly attributed to a [[sports curses|curse]].
==North America==
===Droughts by sport=== *In [[Major League Baseball|MLB]], the [[Chicago Cubs]] suffered a 108-year [[World Series]] drought from 1908 until [[2016 World Series|2016]], when they defeated the [[Cleveland Indians]]. In turn, the Indians inherited the longest active drought, last winning the World Series in [[1948 World Series|1948]]. {{further information|List of Major League Baseball franchise postseason droughts}} *In the [[National Hockey League|NHL]], the [[New York Rangers]] suffered a [[Curse of 1940|54-year]] [[Stanley Cup]] drought from 1940 until [[1994 Stanley Cup Finals|1994]], when they defeated the [[Vancouver Canucks]]. The longest current title drought is shared by two teams: the [[Toronto Maple Leafs]], who have not won the Stanley Cup since [[1966–67 NHL season|1967]], and the [[St. Louis Blues]], who entered the league when it [[1967 NHL expansion|doubled in size]] [[1967–68 NHL season|the following season]], and have not yet won the Cup (and have not appeared in a Cup Final since [[1969-70 NHL season|1970]]). {{further information|List of NHL franchise post-season droughts }} *In the [[National Football League|NFL]], four teams have never appeared in a [[Super Bowl]] (the [[Cleveland Browns]], [[Detroit Lions]], [[Houston Texans]] and [[Jacksonville Jaguars]]), and eight other teams have never won that game. The longest active title drought is that of the [[Arizona Cardinals]] franchise, which last won an NFL championship in the [[1947 NFL season|1947 season]]. The Cardinals have played home games in four cities in three market areas since the team last won a title: Chicago, St. Louis, and the Phoenix suburbs of Tempe and Glendale. {{further information|List of NFL franchise post-season droughts}} *12 [[National Basketball Association|NBA]] teams have never won a championship. The league's longest drought belongs to the [[Sacramento Kings]], who have not won the championship or even been to the NBA Finals since 1951, when they were known as the [[Rochester Royals]]. Sacramento is the fifth city to host the team since it last won a title (Rochester, Cincinnati, Kansas City, and Omaha are the others). {{further information|List of NBA franchise post-season droughts}} *In the [[Canadian Football League|CFL]], the longest current [[Grey Cup]] drought is held by the [[Winnipeg Blue Bombers]] at 28 years. The Blue Bombers last won the Grey Cup in 1990, defeating the Edmonton Eskimos 50–11. Historically, the CFL's longest continuous drought is 56 years (the [[Saskatchewan Roughriders]], from their inception in 1910 to 1966).
*In [[Major League Soccer]] (MLS), the longest current [[MLS Cup]] drought is 22 years, held by three teams, [[FC Dallas]], the [[New England Revolution]], and the [[New York Red Bulls]], as each team has failed to win the league title despite having competed in every MLS season dating back to 1996. All have made MLS Cup Final appearances (Dallas lost to the [[Colorado Rapids]] in [[MLS Cup 2010]], the Red Bulls lost to the [[Columbus Crew SC|Columbus Crew]] in [[MLS Cup 2008]], and New England lost to the [[LA Galaxy|Los Angeles Galaxy]] in [[MLS Cup 2002]], [[MLS Cup 2005]], and [[MLS Cup 2014]] and to the [[Houston Dynamo]] in [[MLS Cup 2006]] and [[MLS Cup 2007]]). [[Atlanta United FC]], [[Los Angeles FC]], [[Minnesota United FC]], the [[Montreal Impact]], [[New York City FC]], [[Orlando City SC]], the [[Philadelphia Union]], and [[Vancouver Whitecaps FC]] have also never won an MLS Cup title, but were added as expansion teams subsequent to 1996. Defunct teams [[CD Chivas USA]], [[Miami Fusion FC]] and the [[Tampa Bay Mutiny]] never won the MLS Cup before they were shut down.{{further information|List of MLS club post-season droughts}}
*With regard to other major domestic trophies, the longest active [[Supporters Shield]] drought is shared by two teams, the Colorado Rapids and the New England Revolution. Neither has won a Supporters Shield despite competing in every MLS season since 1996. Among MLS teams, the longest [[Lamar Hunt U.S. Open Cup]] drought is 20 years, shared by three teams, the Colorado Rapids, New York Red Bulls, and [[San Jose Earthquakes]]. Four other current United States-based teams have not won the Open Cup (the Houston Dynamo, the Philadelphia Union, the [[Portland Timbers]], and [[Real Salt Lake]]), but were added as expansion teams after 1996. The three Canada-based MLS teams, the Montreal Impact, [[Toronto FC]], and Vancouver Whitecaps FC are ineligible as they compete in the [[Voyageurs Cup]].
===Cities with significant droughts=== Several North American cities are considered to have championship droughts among their “Big Four” pro sports teams: * 55 years – [[San Diego]] since 1963 AFL title (pre-Super Bowl, lost 1995 Super Bowl, [[Los Angeles Chargers|Chargers]] relocated beginning 2017), no World Series title (lost 1984 and 1998 World Series), no NBA title ([[Los Angeles Clippers|Clippers]] relocated to Los Angeles in 1984) * 53 years – [[Buffalo, New York|Buffalo]] since 1965 AFL title (pre-Super Bowl, lost 1991 to 1994 Super Bowls), no Stanley Cup title since joining NHL in 1970–71 (lost 1975 and 1999 Stanley Cup final), no NBA title ([[Buffalo Braves|Braves]] relocated to San Diego in 1978). * 48 years – [[Vancouver]] no Stanley Cups since joining NHL in 1970, lost 1982, 1994, and 2011 Stanley Cup finals (The CFL’s [[List of BC Lions seasons|BC Lions]] have won six Grey Cups, last in 2011), no NBA title ([[List of Memphis Grizzlies seasons|Grizzlies]] relocated to Memphis in 2001). * 47 years – [[Milwaukee]] since 1971 NBA title (lost 1982 World Series and 1974 NBA Finals; the city’s [[Marquette University]] won 1977 NCAA basketball championship) * 41 years – [[Portland, Oregon]] since 1977 NBA title (lost 1990 and 1992 NBA Finals; MLS’ Portland Timbers won the 2015 MLS Cup) * 39 years – [[Winnipeg]] no Stanley Cup title since joining NHL in 1979, neither the old nor the current Jets franchise has made the Stanley Cup finals (The CFL’s [[List of Winnipeg Blue Bombers seasons|Blue Bombers]] have won ten Grey Cups, last in 1990) * 39 years – [[Salt Lake City]] has not won a major championship since the [[Utah Jazz|Jazz]] relocated from New Orleans in 1979, lost 1997 and 1998 NBA Finals (MLS’ Real Salt Lake won 2009 MLS Cup, the city’s [[University of Utah]] also won the NCAA Basketball championship in 1944) * 33 years – [[Sacramento, California|Sacramento]] waiting for first since 1985, no NBA championship appearances. The [[Sacramento Monarchs]] won the 2005 [[Women's National Basketball Association|WNBA]] finals and lost the 2006 WNBA finals but folded after the 2009 season. * 30 years – [[Charlotte, North Carolina|Charlotte]] waiting for first since 1988. (Super Bowl appearances in 2004 and 2016; [[List of Charlotte Hornets seasons|the Hornets]] have never made the NBA Finals) * 29 years – [[Calgary]] since 1989 Stanley Cup, lost 2004 Stanley Cup Finals. (The CFL's [[List of Calgary Stampeders seasons|Stampeders]] have won five Grey Cups since then, last in 2018) * 29 years – [[Orlando, Florida|Orlando]] waiting for first since 1989 (lost 1995 and 2009 NBA Finals) * 28 years – [[Edmonton]] since 1990 Stanley Cup, lost 2006 Stanley Cup Finals. (The CFL’s [[List of Edmonton Eskimos seasons|Eskimos]] have won four Grey Cups since then, last in 2015) * 28 years – [[Cincinnati]] since 1990 World Series title, neither the Reds nor the Bengals have returned to the World Series or the Super Bowl respectively. * 27 years – [[San Jose, California|San Jose]] No Stanley Cup title since joining NHL in 1991. (2016 Stanley Cup Finals Appearance) * 27 years – [[Minneapolis–Saint Paul|Minneapolis–St. Paul]] since 1991 World Series title (1969 NFL title (non-Super Bowl), 1954 NBA title, however franchise relocated; no Stanley Cup titles). This is the longest current championship drought for any metro area with a team in each of the “Big Four” leagues. The Twins, Vikings, Timberwolves, and Wild have yet to make a championship appearance since 1991. (The WNBA’s [[Minnesota Lynx]] won championships in 2011, 2013, 2015 and 2017.) * 26 years – [[Ottawa]] No Stanley Cup title since rejoining NHL in 1992. (2007 Stanley Cup Finals Appearance) (The CFL's [[Ottawa Redblacks|Redblacks]] won the 104th Grey Cup in 2016.) * 25 years – [[Montreal]] since 1993 Stanley Cup, the Canadiens have not returned to the Stanley Cup final since then (The CFL's [[List of Montreal Alouettes seasons|Alouettes]] have won three Grey Cups since then, last in 2010) * 25 years – [[Toronto]] since 1993 World Series (1967 Stanley Cup, no NBA titles since joining in 1995, the CFL’s [[List of Toronto Argonauts seasons|Argonauts]] have won five Grey Cups since the Blue Jays’ last World Series title, the Argos’ last in 2017. Toronto FC also claimed the MLS Cup in 2017). Neither the Blue Jays, Raptors, nor Maple Leafs have made their respective finals since 1993. * 23 years – [[Jacksonville, Florida|Jacksonville]] no Super Bowls since Jaguars joined NFL in 1995 * 23 years – [[Atlanta]] since 1995 World Series title (no Super Bowl, NBA, or Stanley Cup titles; [[Atlanta Thrashers|Thrashers]] relocated in 2011), lost 1996 and 1999 World Series and 1999 and 2017 Super Bowls. * 20 years – [[Nashville]] has not won a major championship since Titans relocated, lost 2000 Super Bowl and 2017 Stanley Cup * 18 years – [[Columbus, Ohio]] has not won a major championship since Blue Jackets joined NHL in 2000 and have yet to make a Stanley Cup Finals appearance (MLS’ Columbus Crew won 2008 MLS Cup, the city's [[Ohio State University]] also won eight NCAA football championships, most recently in 2014, and 1960 basketball championship) * 17 years – [[Memphis, Tennessee|Memphis]] has not won a major championship since Grizzlies relocated from Vancouver in 2001 and has yet to make an NBA Finals appearance * 17 years – [[Phoenix, Arizona|Phoenix]] since 2001 World Series, lost 2009 Super Bowl, no NBA Finals appearances since [[1993 NBA Finals|1993]], no Stanley Cup Finals appearance * 14 years – [[Tampa Bay]] since 2004 Stanley Cup, lost 2008 World Series and 2015 Stanley Cup * 12 years – [[Raleigh]] since 2006 Stanley Cup ([[Duke University|Duke]] and [[University of North Carolina|North Carolina]], both located in the region, have each won two NCAA basketball championships during this span), the Hurricanes have not returned to the Stanley Cup Final since then * 11 years – [[Indianapolis]] since 2007 Super Bowl, lost 2010 Super Bowl; Pacers have won no NBA titles and made a solitary NBA Finals appearance [[2000 NBA Finals|in 2000]] * 11 years – [[Anaheim]] since 2007 Stanley Cup * 10 years – [[Detroit]] since 2008 Stanley Cup, lost 2009 Stanley Cup and 2012 World Series, no Super Bowl championships, no NBA title since 2004 * All year counts are as of 2018. <!-- This is a non-included accounting for all other cities with date and title for future reference: Oklahoma City - 0 (team relocated 2009, lost 2012 NBA Finals) New Orleans - 2010 Super Bowl Green Bay - 2011 Super Bowl Dallas - 2011 NBA Finals (lost 2011 World Series) St. Louis - 2011 World Series (lost 2013 World Series) New York metropolitan area - 2012 Super Bowl [Giants] (lost 2012 Stanley Cup [Devils], 2014 Stanley Cup [Rangers] and 2015 World Series [Mets]) Baltimore - 2013 Super Bowl Miami - 2013 NBA Finals (lost 2014 NBA Finals) Seattle - 2014 Super Bowl (lost 2015 Super Bowl) Los Angeles - 2014 Stanley Cup (lost 2017 and 2018 World Series) San Antonio - 2014 NBA Finals San Francisco - 2014 World Series Kansas City - 2015 World Series Denver - 2016 Super Bowl Cleveland - 2016 NBA Finals (lost 2016 World Series, and 2017 and 2018 NBA Finals) Chicago - 2016 World Series Pittsburgh - 2017 Stanley Cup Las Vegas - 0 (gained NHL expansion team in 2017, lost 2018 Stanley Cup) Houston - 2017 World Series Philadelphia - 2018 Super Bowl Washington - 2018 Stanley Cup Oakland - 2018 NBA Finals Boston - 2018 World Series -->
Those who believe in the ''Buffalo Curse''<ref>http://www.buffalocurse.com The Buffalo Curse</ref> cite as examples the four consecutive [[Super Bowl]] losses by [[List of Buffalo Bills seasons|the Buffalo Bills]] from [[Super Bowl XXV|1990]] to [[Super Bowl XXVIII|1993]], as well as the failure of [[List of Buffalo Sabres seasons|the Buffalo Sabres]] to ever win the [[Stanley Cup]]. [[Wide Right (Buffalo Bills)|Wide Right]], [[1999 Stanley Cup Finals|No Goal]], and The [[Music City Miracle]] also contribute to the belief in the Buffalo Curse. Hearts were broken{{citation needed|date=January 2017}} once again in [[2006 Stanley Cup playoffs|2006]], when the Sabres lost to [[2005–06 Carolina Hurricanes season|the Carolina Hurricanes]] in Game 7 of the Eastern Conference Finals, as four of their top six defensemen were lost to injury along with Tim Connolly, the leading scorer of the playoffs at the time of his injury. Even though the Sabres made it back to the conference finals the next year, they lost again, this time to the division rival [[2006–07 Ottawa Senators season|Ottawa Senators]]. It is notable that the Buffalo Bills won the [[American Football League|AFL]] championship in 1964 and 1965. The alleged “curse”, however, has not extended to the city’s fringe or minor league teams—the [[Buffalo Bandits]] of the NLL have won 4 league championships (1992, 1993, 1996, 2008) and six division Championships (1992, 1993, 1994, 2004, 2006, 2008), and the [[Western New York Flash]] of the [[National Women's Soccer League]], based in Buffalo but playing home games in [[Rochester, New York|Rochester]], won the 2016 NWSL Championship. The Flash also won league titles in the two competitions that directly preceded the NWSL—[[Women's Professional Soccer]] in [[2011 Women's Professional Soccer season|2011]] and [[Women's Premier Soccer League Elite|WPSL Elite]] in 2012. The Flash also won the NWSL Shield, awarded to the team with the best regular-season record, in that league's inaugural [[2013 National Women's Soccer League season|2013 season]], but lost the championship final to [[Portland Thorns FC]]. The [[Buffalo Beauts]] of the [[National_Women's_Hockey_League_(2015–)|National Women's Hockey League]] won their first Isobel Cup in the 2016–17 season.<ref>https://thehockeywriters.com/buffalo-beauts-win-2017-nwhl-isobel-cup/</ref>
[[History of the San Diego Padres|The San Diego Padres]] have never won a World Series, believed{{By whom|date=January 2017}} to stem from the ''[[San Diego Sports Curse]]''. San Diego’s former NFL team, [[List of Los Angeles Chargers seasons|the Chargers]] and its former NBA teams, the Rockets and Clippers, never won a Super Bowl or an NBA championship when located within the city. The Padres are tied with the [[Texas Rangers (baseball)|Texas Rangers]] for the most World Series appearances (two) of the seven teams without a World Series championship. The Chargers won the 1963 [[American Football League|AFL]] championship and only appeared in one Super Bowl ([[Super Bowl XXIX]], which they lost to [[1994 San Francisco 49ers season|the San Francisco 49ers]], 49–26).
Some cities with at least three teams have shorter yet notable droughts. [[Minneapolis–Saint Paul]] has not reached a championship series or Super Bowl since [[1991 Minnesota Twins season|the Twins]] won the [[1991 World Series]]. This drought, like the one in Buffalo, has not extended to the market’s fringe or minor league teams—two such teams, the WNBA’s [[Minnesota Lynx]] and the [[Minnesota United FC|Minnesota Stars]] of the [[North American Soccer League|current North American Soccer League]], won league championships in 2011, and the Lynx claimed another league title in 2013 and 2015.
Since the founding of [[Major League Soccer]] in 1996, both Columbus, Ohio and Washington, D.C. have won all three major U.S. soccer trophies (MLS Supporters' Shield, MLS Cup and U.S. Open Cup) during their “Big Four” droughts. Toronto won all three major Canadian soccer trophies (MLS Supporters' Shield, MLS Cup and [[Voyageurs Cup]]) in the [[2017 MLS season]], during its current "Big Four" drought. San Jose has won the MLS Supporters' Shield and MLS Cup during its "Big Four" drought while Portland and Salt Lake City have won the MLS Cup (but no MLS Supporters’ Shields or U.S. Open Cups) during their "Big Four" droughts.
All of the Canadian cities listed above have won multiple Grey Cups during their "Big Four" droughts listed above.
Notable former droughts: * Prior to winning the 2016 NBA Finals, [[Cleveland]] had gone 52 years without a championship in any major professional sport. The drought began after the Cleveland Browns won the 1964 NFL Championship (pre-Super Bowl). The Indians lost two World Series finals, the Browns did not make it to the Super Bowl, and the Cavaliers lost 2 NBA finals during the drought. * [[New Orleans]] had gone 43 years without winning a championship in any major professional sport until the [[New Orleans Saints]] brought the city its first professional sports title via the 2010 Super Bowl. The drought began in 1967, the inaugural year of the New Orleans Saints (the oldest professional sports team still playing in New Orleans). During the drought, neither the Saints nor the Hornets (now the Pelicans) made the Super Bowl or the NBA finals respectively. * [[Seattle]] had gone 35 years without winning a championship in any major professional sport from the 1979 NBA Finals to the 2014 Super Bowl. During the drought, the Mariners never made the World Series, the Seahawks lost the 2006 Super Bowl, and the then SuperSonics (now the [[Oklahoma City Thunder]]) lost the 1996 NBA Finals. Including only Seattle’s current major league sports teams, the Mariners and the Seahawks, increases the former drought's length to 38 years (because the Seahawks were founded in 1976, the earlier of the two teams’ inceptions). * [[Phoenix, Arizona|Phoenix]] had gone 33 years without winning a championship in any major professional sport until [[2001 Arizona Diamondbacks season|the Diamondbacks]] won the [[2001 World Series]]. The drought began in 1968 with the inception of the Phoenix Suns (the oldest professional sports team still playing in Phoenix). During the drought, the Diamondbacks did not make the World Series (albeit only beginning play in 1997), the Cardinals did not make the Super Bowl, the Suns lost two NBA Finals, and the Coyotes did not make the Stanley Cup Final (albeit only beginning play in 1996). The [[Arizona Rattlers]] did win the [[Arena Football League]] twice during this dry spell, in 1994 and 1997. Since the World Series title, however, Phoenix has experienced a 16-year ongoing drought, leaving that World Series title its only major sports championship. * Prior to [[2017–18 Washington Capitals season|the Washington Capitals]] winning the 2018 Stanley Cup Final, [[Washington, D.C.]] had gone 26 years without a championship in any of the “Big Four” sports. The drought began after [[1991 Washington Redskins season|the Redskins]] won [[Super Bowl XXVI]] in 1992. During the drought, the Capitals themselves were the only team from Washington, D.C. that had made it to the championship round, losing the [[1998 Stanley Cup Final]] before winning the 2018 Stanley Cup Final. * Prior to [[2008 Philadelphia Phillies season|the Phillies]] winning the 2008 World Series, [[Philadelphia]] had gone 25 years without a championship. The drought began after [[1982–83 Philadelphia 76ers season|the 76ers]] won the [[1983 NBA Finals]]. [[1986–87 Philadelphia Flyers season|The Flyers]] lost the [[1987 Stanley Cup Finals]], the Phillies lost the [[1993 World Series]], the Flyers again lost the [[1997 Stanley Cup Finals]], the 76ers lost the [[2001 NBA Finals]], and [[2004 Philadelphia Eagles season|the Eagles]] lost [[Super Bowl XXXIX]] in 2005. The drought was explained by locals as the [[Curse of Billy Penn]], in reference to the statue of [[William Penn]] atop [[Philadelphia City Hall]] and a supposed [[gentlemen's agreement]] to build nothing higher than the statute. The "curse" was lifted when a small statute was placed atop the [[Comcast Center]], then the tallest building in Philadelphia. The current [[tallest building in Philadelphia]], the [[Comcast Technology Center]] also has a small statute of William Penn affixed to the highest structural element.<ref>{{Cite news|url=http://www.philly.com/philly/business/comcast/comcast-ironworkers-billy-penn-eagles-nfl-new-tower-20171130.html|title=Ironworkers plant Billy Penn atop new Comcast tower to help Eagles avoid curse - Philly|work=Philly.com|access-date=2018-02-06}}</ref><ref>{{Cite news|url=https://www.nbcphiladelphia.com/news/local/The-Comcast-Technology-Center-Is-Phillys-Tallest-Building-and-Yes-Theres-a-Mini-Billy-Penn-Up-There-461105383.html|title=Yes, There’s a Billy Penn Statue on Philly's New Skyscraper|work=NBC 10 Philadelphia|access-date=2018-02-06|language=en}}</ref> * Prior to winning the 2017 World Series, [[Houston]] had gone 22 years without a championship in any major professional sport. The drought began after the Houston Rockets won the 1995 NBA Finals. The Astros lost the 2005 World Series, the Rockets did not make it to the NBA Finals, and the Texans did not make it to the Super Bowl during the drought.
==Outside North America==
===Association football===
;England
*The [[England national football team|national team]] has not won a major trophy since the [[1966 FIFA World Cup]].<ref>{{cite news|url=http://sport.scotsman.com/sport/Dalglish-believes-strongest-ever-England.2778175.jp |title=Dalglish believes 'strongest ever' England can end 40 years of hurt|work=[[The Scotsman]]|date=24 May 2006}}</ref> *[[Preston North End F.C.]] has not [[English football champions|won the league]] since 1890. *[[Newcastle United F.C.|Newcastle United]] has not won a major trophy since 1969.<ref>{{cite news|url=http://www.dailymail.co.uk/sport/football/article-1070049/Newcastles-1969-Fairs-Cup-winners-united.html |title=Fairs Cup winners to be re-united|work=[[Daily Mail]]|date=6 October 2008}}</ref> *[[West Bromwich Albion F.C.|West Bromwich Albion]] has not [[English football champions|won the league]] since 1920. *[[Manchester City F.C.|Manchester City]] went 35 years between winning major trophies, from the 1976 League Cup<ref>{{cite news| url=http://sport.scotsman.com/sport/Darren-Fletcher-the-destroyer-revels.6025427.jp| work=[[The Scotsman]]| first=Simon| last=Stone| title=Darren Fletcher the destroyer revels in prolonging City drought| date=29 January 2010 |accessdate=29 January 2010}}</ref> to the 2011 FA Cup. *[[Liverpool F.C.|Liverpool]] has not [[English football champions|won the league]] since 1990.<ref>{{cite news| url=https://www.independent.co.uk/sport/football/premier-league/liverpool-can-end-title-drought-says-rush-1675670.html| title=Liverpool can end title drought, says Rush|work=[[The Independent]]|date=28 April 2009}}</ref> *[[Manchester United F.C.|Manchester United]] went 26 years without [[English football champions|winning the league]] from 1967 until they ended their drought by winning the newly formed [[Premier League]] in 1993.<ref>{{cite web |url=http://espnfc.com/manager/_/id/30/sir-alex-ferguson?cc=5739 |title=Sir Alex Ferguson |work=www.espnfc.com |publisher=ESPN Internet Ventures |date= |accessdate=30 March 2014 |quote=In the newly founded '[[Premier League]]', [[Alex Ferguson|Ferguson]] found more success; the arrival of enigmatic Frenchman [[Eric Cantona]] proved to be the final piece of the jigsaw and United finally won the league title in [[1992–93 in English football|1992–93]], ending a 26-year drought.}}</ref> *[[Tottenham Hotspur F.C.|Tottenham Hotspur]] has not [[English football champions|won the league]] since 1961. *[[Fulham Football Club|Fulham]] were founded in 1879 and have never won a major trophy<ref>https://www.11v11.com/teams/fulham/</ref>. *[[Crystal Palace F.C.|Crystal Palace]] were founded in 1905 and have never won a major trophy. The closest they have come to winning a major trophy were in The 1990 and 2016 FA Cup finals. On both occasions they lost to [[Manchester United]]<ref>http://www.croydonadvertiser.co.uk/can-crystal-palace-and-brighton-supporters-really-be-considered-glory-hunting-fans/story-30417519-detail/story.html</ref>. *[[Everton F.C.|Everton]] have not won a major trophy for 22 years. The last time they lifted any trophy was in 1995 when they defeated [[Manchester United]] 1-0 in The FA Cup final<ref>http://www.dailymail.co.uk/sport/football/article-3340669/Everton-haven-t-won-trophy-20-years-Capital-One-Cup-important-club.html</ref>.
;Germany
*[[1.FC Nurnberg]] is one of the most successful teams in German footballing history. But their last league league title came in The 1967-1968 [[Bundesliga]] season.<ref>https://thesefootballtimes.co/2017/01/12/how-fc-nurnberg-went-from-bundesliga-champions-to-relegation-within-12-months/</ref> *[[Hertha BSC]] won The German Championship which is the equivalent of the bundesliga twice in 1930 and 1931 but have not won the league since. As of 2017, it has been 86 years since Hertha has won the league.<ref>http://theworldgame.sbs.com.au/blog/2017/08/10/meet-union-berlin-germanys-fan-powered-success-story</ref> *[[Schalke 04]] haven't won the German League since 1958.
;Italy
*[[Genoa C.F.C.|Genoa]] has not [[List of Italian football champions|won the league]] since 1924, and has not won a major trophy since 1937. *[[Pro Vercelli]] has not won a major trophy (Italian league) since 1922. *[[Bologna Football Club 1909]] has won seven [[Serie A]] titles but their last came in The 1963-1964 season, fifty-five years ago<ref>http://www.juventus.com/en/news/news/2013/bologna-in-the-spotlight.php</ref>.
;Portugal
*[[S.L. Benfica|Benfica]] has not won a European trophy since the [[1961–62 European Cup]]; the club has lost eight European finals since then, the last one in [[2014 UEFA Europa League Final|2014]].<ref>{{cite web |url=http://www.cbc.ca/sports/soccer/sevilla-seals-europa-league-title-with-shootout-win-over-benfica-1.2643373 |title=Sevilla seals Europa League title with shootout win over Benfica |agency=Associated Press |publisher=CBC |date=14 May 2014 |accessdate=15 May 2014}}</ref>
;Netherlands
*[[Vitesse Arnhem]] won The 2017 [[KNVB Cup]] defeating [[AZ Alkmaar]] 2-0 in the final. This was the club's first trophy in their 125-year history.<ref>http://www.dailymail.co.uk/sport/football/article-4460818/Chelsea-loanees-star-Vitesse-Arnheim-win-Dutch-Cup.html</ref>
;Scotland
*The [[Scotland national football team|national team]] has failed to qualify for a major tournament since the [[1998 FIFA World Cup]]. *[[Dundee F.C.|Dundee]] has not won the [[Scottish Cup]] since [[1909–10 in Scottish football|1910]].<ref>{{cite news |url=https://www.telegraph.co.uk/sport/2405020/Scottish-Cup-Final-Dundee-defy-sinking-feeling.html |first=Roddy |last=Forsyth |work=Daily Telegraph |date=31 May 2003 |accessdate=17 May 2014 |title=Scottish Cup Final: Dundee defy sinking feeling}}</ref> *[[Hibernian F.C.|Hibernian]] ended a 114-year wait to win the [[Scottish Cup]] in [[2015–16 in Scottish football|2016]], having not won the competition since [[1901–02 in Scottish football|1902]].<ref>{{cite news |url=http://sport.scotsman.com/top-stories/Edinburghs-real-disgrace-Hibs-have.2253386.jp | title=Edinburgh's real disgrace? Hibs have not won the cup since Buffalo Bill was in town|work=[[Scotland On Sunday]] |publisher=Johnston Publishing|date=20 May 2001}}</ref><ref>{{cite web |url=https://www.bbc.co.uk/sport/football/36292302 |title=Rangers 2–3 Hibernian |first=Richard |last=Wilson |work=BBC Sport |publisher=BBC |date=21 May 2016 |accessdate=21 May 2016}}</ref> The club lost ten [[Scottish Cup Final]]s between these victories. *[[St Johnstone F.C.|St Johnstone]] ended a 130-year wait to win a major national trophy ([[list of Scottish football champions|Scottish league championship]], Scottish Cup or [[Scottish League Cup]]) when they won the [[2013–14 Scottish Cup]].<ref>{{cite news |url=http://www.scotsman.com/sport/football/latest/st-johnstone-stevie-may-tommy-wright-win-awards-1-3187383 |title=St Johnstone: Stevie May, Tommy Wright win awards|first=Stephen |last=Halliday |work=Scotsman |publisher=Johnston Publishing |date=14 November 2013 |accessdate=25 November 2013}}</ref><ref>{{cite news |url=https://www.bbc.co.uk/sport/0/football/27354162 |title=St Johnstone 2–0 Dundee Utd |work=BBC Sport |publisher=BBC |date=17 May 2014 |accessdate=17 May 2014 |first=Richard |last=Wilson}}</ref>
;Spain
*[[Real Betis]] has not won the league since [[1934–35 La Liga|1935]], which actually is their only [[La Liga]] championship. The other top-team of [[Seville]], [[Sevilla FC]] won his last La Liga championship in [[1945–46 La Liga|1946]], when the team won its only league title. *[[Real Madrid]] won 6 of the 11 first [[UEFA Champions League|European Cup]] ever disputed, and then entered in a 32-year period without winning a single European top championship. This was broken in [[1997–98 UEFA Champions League|1998]], when Los Blancos won their seventh European top championship. This was followed by another two Champions League titles in the following four seasons. *[[Arenas de Getxo]] is a [[Basque Country (autonomous community)|Basque]] team which currently plays in the Spanish [[Tercera División]], the fourth level in Spanish football system. The team competed in the first seven La Liga seasons starting in [[La Liga 1929|1929]]. Previously Arenas had won the [[Copa del Rey|Spanish Cup]] in [[1919 Copa del Rey|1919]], so the drought is now 93 years old. *[[Sevilla FC]] have not won [[La Liga]] since their one and only triumph came in The 1945/1946 season.<ref>https://www.theguardian.com/football/blog/2017/feb/27/now-sevilla-can-think-about-la-liga-title-charge-after-besting-betis</ref>
;France
*[[Association Sportive de Saint-Étienne]] also known as Saint-Etienne are the most successful team in [[Ligue 1]] history winning 10 titles but their last came in the 1980-1981 season<ref>https://www.telegraph.co.uk/football/2016/12/12/saint-etienne-scouting-report-need-know-manchester-uniteds-europa/</ref>. *[[Olympique Gymnaste Club Nice Côte d'Azur]] also known simply as Nice won four [[Ligue 1]] titles in the 1950s, their last title was in the 1958-1959 season, 60 years since their last title win<ref>http://www.ligue1.com/ligue1/article/so-nice-in-nice-for-title-challengers.htm</ref>.
;Argentina
*The [[Argentina national football team|national team]] has not won a major tournament since the [[1993 Copa América]], accounting for 24 years without an official championship to 2017.<ref>{{cite news |url=https://www.theguardian.com/football/2016/jun/26/argentina-copa-america-first-trophy-23-years-chile |title=Argentina on verge of first trophy for 23 years – but beware revitalized Chile |first=Jonathan |last=Wilson |work=The Guardian |publisher= |date=26 June 2016 |accessdate=6 February 2017}}</ref> *[[Argentine Primera División]] regulars [[Gimnasia y Esgrima de La Plata]] has not won a professional league championship since the Professional Primera División inception in 1931. *Other famous droughts on the Argentine Primera División were the 34-year-long drought for [[Racing Club de Avellaneda]] between 1966 and 2001 and the 18-year-long drought for [[Club Atlético River Plate]] between 1957 and 1975.
===Australian Rules Football=== In the [[Australian Football League|VFL/AFL]] (1897–present), the longest premiership drought was that of [[Sydney Swans|South Melbourne/Sydney]], who won their third premiership in 1933, but did not win another premiership until 2005, 72 years later. The second-longest drought in the league was that of [[St Kilda Football Club|St Kilda]] (69 years) who won their first and only senior premiership in 1966. [[Melbourne Demons]] currently hold the longest active drought having not won a premiership since 1964.
;Longest VFL/AFL premiership droughts
{| class="wikitable sortable" style="text-align:center" !Years !Team !Previous [[List of Australian Football League premiers|VFL/AFL Premiership]] !Next VFL/AFL Premiership !class="unsortable"|Grand Finals during drought |- |72 |[[Sydney Swans|South Melbourne/Sydney]] |[[1933 VFL Grand Final|1933]] |2005 |1934, 1935, 1936, 1945, 1996 |- |69 |[[St Kilda Football Club|St Kilda]] |Never |1966 |1913, 1965 |- |62 |[[Western Bulldogs|Footscray/Western Bulldogs]] |[[1954 VFL Grand Final|1954]] |[[2016 AFL Grand Final|2016]] |1961 |- |52 |[[Fitzroy Football Club|Fitzroy]] |1944 |<small>Never</small> <sup>1</sup> | |- |55 |[[Melbourne Football Club|Melbourne]] |1964 |Drought active |1988, 2000 |- |50 |[[North Melbourne Football Club|North Melbourne]] |<small>Never</small> |1975 |1950, 1974 |- |53 |[[St Kilda Football Club|St Kilda]] |1966 |Drought active |1971, 1997, 2009, 2010, 2010 replay |- |44 |[[Geelong Football Club|Geelong]] |1963 |2007 |1967, 1989, 1992, 1994, 1995 |- |36 |[[Hawthorn Football Club|Hawthorn]] |<small>Never</small> |1961 | |- |37 |[[Richmond Football Club|Richmond]] |1980 |[[2017 AFL Grand Final|2017]] |1982 |- |32 |[[Collingwood Football Club|Collingwood]] |1958 |1990 |1960, 1964, 1966, 1970, 1977, 1977 replay, 1979, 1980, 1981 <sup>'''2'''</sup> |- |29 |[[Western Bulldogs|Footscray]] |<small>Never</small> |1954 | |- |28 |[[Geelong Football Club|Geelong]] |<small>Never</small> |1925 |<sup>'''3'''</sup> |- |}
<sup>1</sup> Fitzroy merged with the Brisbane Bears in 1996, having never appeared in another Grand Final after their 1944 premiership, to become the Brisbane Lions. The new Lions team is more referred to as a continuation of the old Brisbane team than of Fitzroy. <br /> <sup>2</sup> This is commonly known as the "[[Colliwobbles]]". <br /> <sup>3</sup> Geelong finished runners-up in 1897, but no Grand Final was required under the round-robin finals system in place that year.
===Baseball===
; South Korea
*[[Lotte Giants]] has not won a [[KBO League]] since 1992.
===Rugby league=== The [[Parramatta Eels]] hold the longest active drought in the [[National Rugby League|NRL]] totalling thirty-three years, having not won a premiership since 1986. For reference, Parramatta's first premiership came in its 35th season in 1981. The next longest active drought is twenty-five years held by the [[Canberra Raiders]] who have not won a premiership (nor appeared in a Grand Final) since 1994.
The [[North Sydney Bears]] held the longest premiership drought in the [[National Rugby League|NSWRL/NRL]] with a total of seventy-seven years. This lasted between their second premiership in 1922 up until the end of 1999 when they began a short-lived merger with [[Manly-Warringah Sea Eagles|Manly-Warringah]] known as the [[Northern Eagles]]. North Sydney also had the longest drought waiting for the next grand final appearance which stood at fifty six years. Their last grand final appearance was against Newtown in 1943<ref>https://www.sunshinecoastdaily.com.au/news/who-has-the-longest-drought-in-australian-sport/3095611/</ref>. This merger was dissolved after three seasons resulting in [[North Sydney Bears|North Sydney]] being expelled from the league. As of 2018 they are still applying for re-entry.
The [[Cronulla-Sutherland Sharks]] won their first premiership in 2016 after 50 seasons of NSWRL/ARL/Super League/NRL competition – the longest wait for a first title that any club has endured. Prior to this, the Sharks had played in four Grand Finals (including a replay in 1978) for one draw and three losses.
The [[South Sydney Rabbitohs]] won 20 premierships in the [[NSWRL]] from the league's inception in 1908 until 1971, but had to wait to win their 21st title (their 1st in the [[NRL]] era) until 2014, a drought lasting 41 years (the Rabbitohs were inactive in 2000-01).
The Gold Coast itself as a city has suffered a premiership drought of sorts. The original Gold Coast side was founded in 1988 as The Gold Coast-Tweed Giants and then were rebranded three times. First as The Gold Coast Seagulls, then Gold Coast Gladiators and then The Gold Coast Chargers. In 2006, The [[Gold Coast Titans]] entered the competition. Since 1988, no Gold Coast team has made a grand final or won a premiership. The best season for any of the franchises was in 2010, when Gold Coast Titans made the preliminary final<ref>https://www.nrl.com/news/2018/02/23/the-fall-and-rise-of-the-gold-coast-titans/</ref> .
[[Hull F.C.]] lost seven consecutive [[Challenge Cup]] Final appearances at [[Wembley Stadium]] between 1959 and 2008.<ref name = "hull">{{cite web |url=https://www.bbc.co.uk/news/uk-england-humber-23673360 |title=Rugby League: Will Hull FC's Wembley hoodoo strike again? |work=BBC News |publisher=BBC |first=Trevor |last=Gibbons |date=23 August 2013 |accessdate=24 August 2013}}</ref> The team won two Challenge Cups during that time, but the final victories were at [[Elland Road]] (1982 replay) and the [[Millennium Stadium]] ([[2005 Challenge Cup|2005]], while Wembley was being rebuilt).<ref name = "hull"/>
[[Warrington Wolves]] were founded in 1876 and have won three premierships in their history with the last being in 1955. Out of all the current teams in The English Super League they have waited longer than any other team to win their next premiership. As of 2018, it has been 63 years since Warrington had won the premiership.<ref>https://www.bbc.com/sport/live/rugby-league/37307917</ref><ref>http://www.warringtonguardian.co.uk/sport/15085532.NOSTALGIA__Season_openers_in_Wolves_history/</ref>
The [[Castleford Tigers]] currently hold the record for the longest time to win a premiership in either The Super League or The NRL. Founded in 1926, Castleford have only played in three grand finals (1938,1969 & 2017) and for the first time in their 92-year history they finished first in The 2017 Super League season to claim their first ever league leaders shield. Castleford's drought of 92 years to wait for a first title eclipses The [[Cronulla Sutherland Sharks]] record in The NRL of 49 years who had the longest drought of any professional rugby league team in Australia to wait for a first title.<ref>http://www.yorkshirepost.co.uk/sport/rugby-league/castleford-tigers/luke-gale-in-race-against-time-to-help-castleford-tigers-push-for-grand-final-1-8750268</ref><ref>https://www.bbc.com/sport/rugby-league/40698382</ref><ref>http://sport.bt.com/rugby-league/castleford-win-league-leaders-shield-for-first-time-S11364204765897</ref>
===Rugby union=== In [[Rugby union in France|France]], [[ASM Clermont Auvergne]] had a championship history arguably as tortured as the most "cursed" teams in North America or Australia. From their formation in 1911 through 2009, they had never won a national title despite making the championship final 10 times, and had come within a converted try in six of those games.
The drought culminated in three consecutive title-game losses in 2007 through 2009, and ''Les Jaunards'' finally broke through in [[2009–10 Top 14 season|2010]] to win their first title after 91 years of competition (they did not play in 1915–1919 or 1940–1942 due to World War I and World War II).
===Cricket=== Queensland won the [[Sheffield Shield]] in 1994/95, its 63rd season of competition, having finished second on 11 occasions in that time. In 46 of those years, only five teams competed for the Shield, as Tasmania were admitted in 1977/78 (winning the Shield in 2007/08, after 30 years).
[[Somerset County Cricket Club|Somerset]] have not yet won the English [[County Championship]] since they were admitted to the competition in 1891.<ref>{{cite news |url=https://www.independent.co.uk/sport/cricket/somerset-always-the-bridesmaids-of-the-county-championship-8566614.html |title=Somerset: Always the bridesmaids of the County Championship |first=Jack |last=Pitt-Brooke |work=The Independent |publisher= |date=9 April 2013 |accessdate=24 August 2013}}</ref><ref>{{cite news |url=https://www.telegraph.co.uk/sport/cricket/international/england/2610086/Somerset-scent-a-piece-of-history-Cricket.html |title=Somerset scent a piece of County Championship history |work=Daily Telegraph |first=Scyld |last=Berry |date=23 August 2008 |accessdate=24 August 2013}}</ref> [[Gloucestershire County Cricket Club|Gloucestershire]] have not won the Championship since it was constituted in 1890, but won three unofficial "Champion County" titles in the 1870s, the last in 1874.
[[Northamptonshire County Cricket Club|Northamptonshire]] have not yet won the Championship since being admitted to the competition in 1905, after the club was granted first class status.
The [[England cricket team]] has never won a 50 over ICC world cup, even though England founded the game of cricket.
==See also== *[[National Hockey League|NHL]] *[[National Football League|NFL]] *[[National Basketball Association|NBA]] *[[Major League Baseball|MLB]] *[[Major League Soccer|MLS]] *[[List of Current NFL franchise post-season droughts]] *[[List of MLB franchise postseason droughts|List of Major League Baseball franchise post-season droughts]] *[[List of NBA franchise post-season droughts|List of National Basketball Association franchise post-season droughts]] *[[List of NHL franchise post-season droughts|List of National Hockey League franchise post-season droughts]] *[[List of MLS club post-season droughts|List of Major League Soccer club post-season droughts]] *[[List of CHL franchise post-season droughts|List of Canadian Hockey League franchise post-season droughts]]

revision.text:
A '''European Championship''' is a top level [[international]] sports competition between [[Europe|European]] athletes or sports teams representing their respective countries or professional [[sports club|sports clubs]].
== List of championships == {{Div col}} ;Aquatics and water sports * [[LEN European Aquatics Championships]] * [[European Short Course Swimming Championships]] * [[European Water Polo Championship]] * [[European Masters Swimming Championships]]
;Athletics * [[European Athletics Championships]] * [[European Athletics Indoor Championships]] * [[European Athletics U23 Championships]] * [[European Athletics U20 Championships]] * [[European Mountain Running Championships]]
;Australian rules football * [[EU Cup]] * [[AFL Europe Championship]]
;Auto racing * [[European Championship (auto racing)]] (1931–1939 only) * [[European Formula Two Championship]] (1967–1984) * [[European Touring Car Championship]] (1963–1988; 2000–2004) * [[European Rally Championship]] * [[FIA European Rallycross Championship]] * [[FIA GT3 European Championship]]
;Badminton * [[European Badminton Championships]]
;Baseball * [[European Baseball Championship]]
;Bandy * [[European Bandy Championships]] (1913)
;Basketball * [[EuroBasket]] * [[EuroBasket Women]]
;Biathlon * [[Biathlon European Championships]]
;Boxing * [[European Amateur Boxing Championships]]
;Brazilian jiu-jitsu * [[European Championship (Brazilian jiu-jitsu)]]
;Canoeing
* [[Canoe Sprint European Championships]] * [[European Canoe Slalom Championships]]
;Chess * [[European Individual Chess Championship]]
;Cricket * [[European Cricket Championship]] * [[European Twenty20 Championship]] * [[Women's European Cricket Championship]] * [[European Affiliates Championship]]
;Curling * [[European Curling Championships]]
;[[European Cycling Championships|Cycling]] *BMX: [[European BMX Championships]] *Cyclo-cross: [[European Cyclo-cross Championships]] *Mountain bike: [[European Mountain Bike Championships]] *Road cycling: [[European Road Championships]] *Track cycling: [[UEC European Track Championships]]
;Darts * [[European Championship (darts)]]
;Equestrian * [[European Dressage Championships]] * [[European Eventing Championships]] * [[European Show Jumping Championships]]
;Fencing * [[World Fencing Championships]], open only to European fencers from 1921 to 1937 * [[European Fencing Championships]] (1981–)
;Field hockey * [[EuroHockey Nations Championship]] * [[EuroHockey Indoor Nations Championship]]
;Figure skating * [[European Figure Skating Championships]]
;Fistball * [[Fistball European Championships]]
;Football and Beach Soccer * [[UEFA European Championship]] * [[UEFA Women's Championship]] * [[Euro Beach Soccer League]]
;Futsal * [[UEFA Futsal Championship]] * [[UEFS Futsal Championship]]
;Go * [[European Go Championship]]
;Gymnastics * [[Aerobic Gymnastics European Championships]] * [[European Acrobatics Championships]] * [[European Men's Artistic Gymnastics Championships]] * [[European TeamGym Championships]] * [[European Trampoline Championships]] * [[European Women's Artistic Gymnastics Championships]] * [[Rhythmic Gymnastics European Championships]]
;Handball and Beach Handball * [[European Men's Handball Championship]] * [[European Women's Handball Championship]] * [[European Beach Handball Championship]] * [[European Wheelchair Handball Nations’ Tournament]]
;Ice hockey * [[Ice Hockey European Championships]]
;Ice sledge hockey * [[IPC Ice Sledge Hockey European Championships]]
;Judo * [[European Judo Championships]]
;Kickboxing * [[List of WAKO Amateur European Championships|W.A.K.O. Amateur European Kickboxing Championships]]

'''Extended length conditioning''' (ELC) also known as "end range conditioning" is a type of [[physical exercise]] that strengthens the body muscles through a wide range of flexible motions.<ref>Paul Zaichik, [https://books.google.com.ng/books?id=jjl3AAAACAAJ&dq=Extended+Length+Conditioning&hl=en&sa=X&redir_esc=y "ElasticSteel Method of Athletic Conditioning: The Finest in Strength and Flexibility Preparation"],.</ref> ELC exercises are end range exercises or deep range exercises that contract the muscles from full stretch.<ref>Josh Bryant, [http://www.muscleandfitness.com/workouts/workout-tips/6-best-extended-range-motion-moves-mass-0 "6 Best Extended Range Of Motion Moves For Mass"], ''muscleandfitness.com'',.</ref><ref> [http://www.family-friendly-fun.com/family-health/therapy/range-of-motion.htm "Range of motion (ROM) exercises for joint mobility "], ''family-friendly-fun.com'',.</ref> A typical example of extended length conditioning is the [[Deadlift|stiffed legged deadlift]] which is meant for strengthening one of the three posterior thigh muscles referred to as "[[hamstring]]".<ref>Josh Bryant, [http://www.elasticsteel.net/Articles.asp?ID=158 "Leg Circles Part II – Stretching the Hip Muscles for Higher Kicks"], ''elasticsteel.net'',.</ref>
==Benefits== Extended length conditioning exercises can help people get more comfortable, feel stronger and protected in a deep range.<ref>[https://www.easyflexibility.com/products/extended-length-conditioning-for-lower-body?variant=844272217 "Extended Length Conditioning for Lower Body"], ''easyflexibility.com'',.</ref> The exercises allow for better cold flexibility and faster warm up. They also encourage prevention of injuries developed during muscle stretching.<ref>Thomas Kurz, [https://books.google.com.ng/books?id=eo4FwKPQppsC&dq=Extended+Length+Conditioning&source=gbs_book_similarbooks "Stretching Scientifically: A Guide to Flexibility Training"],.</ref><ref>Paul Zaichik, [http://www.fightingarts.com/reading/article.php?id=530 "Leg Circles Part 2– Stretching the Hip Muscles for Higher Kicks"],.</ref> Extended length conditioning exercises help people to stay safe and maintain their flexibility gains. They also add to the overall strength of the individuals.<ref>Pavel Tsatsouline, [https://books.google.com.ng/books?id=buyFfeuFmekC&dq=Extended+Length+Conditioning&source=gbs_book_similarbooks "Relax Into Stretch: Instant Flexibility Through Mastering Muscle Tension"],.</ref>
==Side effects== Extended length conditioning can lead to injuries if the individual fails to warm up properly just like the case with other similar exercises. Injuries can occur when the movement is jerky during ELC exercises.<ref>[https://wellnesswinz.com/2015/11/02/different-types-of-exercise-pros-and-cons/ "Different Types of Exercise: Pros and Cons"], ''wellnesswinz.com'',.</ref><ref>[https://mollythrodahl.wordpress.com/2012/02/26/pros-and-cons-of-strength-training-to-failure/ "Pros and Cons of Strength Training to Failure"], ''mollythrodahl.wordpress.com'',February 26, 2012.</ref>
==See also== * [[Deadlift]] * [[Muscle hypertrophy]] * [[Strength training]]
==References== {{Reflist}}
[[Category:Physical exercise]]

revision.comment: removed grandparent category of [[Category:1424 in Scotland]]
revision.text:
'''The Football Act 1424''' was passed by the [[Parliament of Scotland]] in the reign of [[James I of Scotland|James I]]. It became law on 26 May 1424, one of a set of [[statute]]s passed that day; it is recorded as ''James I. 1424 (May 26) c.18'' in the Record Edition of the statutes, and ''James I. Parl. 1-1424 c.17'' in the Duodecimo Edition. The title of the Act was "Of playing at the fut ball".
The Act stated that ''it is statut and the king forbiddis that na man play at the fut ball under the payne of iiij d''<ref>{{cite book | last = Craigie | first = William A | authorlink = William Craigie | title = A Dictionary of the Older Scottish Tongue: from the Twelfth Century to the End of the Seventeenth | publisher = [[Aberdeen University Press]], [[Oxford University Press]] | location = | pages = | url = http://www.dsl.ac.uk/dsl/getent4.php?query=futeball | isbn =|display-authors=etal}}</ref> - in other words, playing [[football]] was forbidden by the King, and punishable by a fine of four [[Penny Scots|pence]].
The Act remained in force for several centuries, although somewhat unsurprisingly, it fell into disuse. It was finally repealed by the [[Statute Law Revision (Scotland) Act 1906]].
Three further 15th century Acts (in 1457, 1470 and 1490) explicitly prohibit both football and golf (see [[Golf in Scotland]]) during ''wappenschaws'' ({{lang-en|[[Muster (military)|musterings]]}}) for [[archery]] practice.<ref>{{cite book |last = Craigie |first = William A |authorlink = |title = A Dictionary of the Older Scottish Tongue: from the Twelfth Century to the End of the Seventeenth |publisher = Aberdeen University Press, Oxford University Press |location = |pages = |url = http://www.dsl.ac.uk/dsl/getent4.php?query=golf |isbn = |display-authors = etal |deadurl = yes |archiveurl = https://web.archive.org/web/20070929091714/http://www.dsl.ac.uk/dsl/getent4.php?query=golf |archivedate = 2007-09-29 |df = }}</ref><ref>[http://www.rps.ac.uk/ Parliamentary Register]</ref>
==See also== *[[Ba game]] *[[Medieval football]] *[[Football in Scotland]] *[[Scotland in the Late Middle Ages]] *[[Sport in Scotland]]
==References== {{Reflist}} * [[Gordon Donaldson]], ''Scottish Historical Documents.'' Scottish Academic Press, 1970. Reprinted 1974. *''Chronological Table of the Statutes 1235-1991'', HMSO, 1993.
{{UK legislation}}

{{for|articles on human disabilities|Disability}} {{Other uses|Handicap (disambiguation){{!}}Handicap}} {{multiple issues| {{Refimprove|date=January 2014}} {{Globalize |date=January 2014 |discuss=Talk:Handicapping#Globalize }} }} '''Handicapping''', in [[sport]] and [[game]]s, is the practice of assigning advantage through scoring compensation or other advantage given to different contestants to equalize the chances of winning. The word also applies to the various methods by which the advantage is calculated. In principle, a more experienced participant is disadvantaged, or a less experienced or capable participant is advantaged, in order to make it possible for the less experienced participant to win whilst maintaining fairness. Handicapping is used in scoring many games and competitive sports, including [[Go (board game)|go]], [[shogi]], [[chess]], [[croquet]], [[golf]], [[bowling]], [[polo]], [[basketball]], and [[track and field]] events. Handicap races are common in clubs which encourage all levels of participants, such as swimming or in cycling clubs and sailing clubs, or which allow participants with a variety of standards of equipment. Often races, contests or tournaments where this practice is competitively employed are known as ''Handicaps''.
'''Handicapping''' also refers to the various methods by which spectators can predict and quantify the results of a sporting match. The term is applied to the practice of predicting the result of a competition, such as for purposes of betting against the [[Spread betting|point spread]]. A favored team that wins by less than the point spread still wins the game, but bets on that team lose.
In either case the '''handicapper''' is the person who sets the handicaps for the activity. <!-- Handicapper redirects to this article -->
==Etymology== The term ''handicap'' derives from [[hand-in-cap]], referring to a system wherein players placed bets or money into the cap of a neutral arbiter to reach an agreement as to the relative values of items sought to be traded.<ref>"handicap, n." The Oxford English Dictionary. 2nd ed. 1989. OED Online. Oxford University Press. 8 Oct. 2008 {{cite web |url=http://dictionary.oed.com/cgi/entry/50102189 |title=Archived copy |accessdate=2008-10-08 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20110524184911/http://dictionary.oed.com/cgi/entry/50102189 |archivedate=May 24, 2011 |df= }}.</ref>
==Competition handicapping== In a 'result adjustment' style handicap event, the outcome may be adjusted by some factor determined by the handicap. Some forms of car or yacht racing.<ref>{{cite web|title=History of the PY|publisher=Royal Yachting Association|url=http://www.rya.org.uk/SiteCollectionDocuments/technical/Web%20Documents/py-general/RYA_G01_Panel_15_2000x1500_07.pdf|accessdate=23 June 2013}}</ref> In this case, the winner, on elapsed time, may differ from the fastest competitor when the times have been adjusted for the different competitors' handicaps.
In a 'pursuit' style handicap race, all participants are clocked in a time trial before the race. When this takes place at the same event as the main race, it is known as the handicap. In the race itself, the participants do not all start at the same "Go"; the starts are staggered, based on the handicaps. The slowest swimmer, or cyclist, for example, starts first and the fastest starts last, making the end of the race (hopefully) close. An ideal handicap race is one in which all participants finish at the same time.<ref>[http://www.ukhorseracing.co.uk/newtoracing/HandicappingExplained.asp] UK Horse Racing. Accessed 5 February 2011.</ref> The winner is the person who beats his or her own time.
Similarly, physically staggered starting positions can be used, for example, in greyhound racing a handicap race is where greyhounds (based on their ability) start from different [[Greyhound racing in the United Kingdom#Racing Jacket Colours and Starting Traps|starting traps]] set at different measurements from the finish line, and in human foot racing, for example, the [[Stawell Gift]].
Some motorsport events, especially in [[sports car racing]], demand teams to stop the vehicle in the pitbox a fixed period of time depending on the drivers' classification, thus giving advantage to less skilled drivers. An example of a championship using this system is the [[International GT Open]]. The advantage of this system over [[ballast weight]] systems is that vehicles have the normal performance on track, so better drivers will be able to recover time and overtake slower drivers.
Contrarily, horse race handicaping is implemented using extra weight.
===Horse racing=== {{main|Handicap (horse racing)}} A handicap race in horse racing is a race in which horses carry different weights, allocated by the handicapper. A better horse will carry a heavier weight, to give him or her a disadvantage when racing against slower horses. The handicapper's goal in assigning handicap weights is to enable all the horses to finish together (in a dead heat).
The skill in betting on a handicap horse race is in determining which horse can overcome its handicap.<ref>{{cite web |url=http://www.britishhorseracing.com/inside_horseracing/about/whatwedo/handicapping.asp |title=Archived copy |accessdate=2011-02-05 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20101031095844/http://britishhorseracing.com/inside_horseracing/about/whatwedo/handicapping.asp |archivedate=2010-10-31 |df= }} British Horseracing Authority. Accessed 5 February 2011.</ref>
===Golf=== {{main|Handicap (golf)}} Handicapping in the game of golf is by manipulating the golfer's score (number of strokes).
===Chess=== {{main|Handicap (chess)}} Types of chess handicaps include: * the stronger player surrenders a certain piece or pieces * the weaker player has extra moves at the beginning of the game * the weaker player has extra time on the chess clock * the odds-giver to deliver checkmate with a specified piece
===Go=== {{main|Handicap (go)}} Handicapping in go includes the weaker player being given an advantage by placing a number of stones before the stronger player commences, and by final points adjustment.
===Shogi=== {{main|Handicap (shogi)}} Handicapping in shogi is achieved by removing one or more pieces from the stronger player's side. Shogi (Japanese chess) and many of its variants have [[Shogi#Player ranking and handicaps|handicaps]].
===Gliding=== {{main|Glider (sailplane)}}
===Polo=== {{main|Handicap (polo)}} The polo handicap is an estimation of the player's worth to his or her team. It is an overall rating of a player's horsemanship, team play, knowledge of the game, strategy and horses. The difference between the total of the polo handicaps for the players on each team is then used to determine the minimum score difference for the better team to score to enable them to win.
===Sailing=== {{main|Handicap (sailing)}} Handicaps for sailing vessels in sailing races have varied throughout history, and they also vary by country, and by sailing organisation. Sailing handicap standards exist internationally, nationally, and within individual sailing clubs.
Sailing race handicaps may be based on vessel capability and-or crew experience, and today typically adjust the time a vessel takes to reach the finish point of the race.
===Tennis=== {{main|Handicap (tennis)}}
===Motor cycle speedway=== [[Calculated Match Average]] is a handicap calculated for every motorcycle speedway rider.
==Outcome prediction== ===Middle and arbitrage bets=== There are strategies that involve differences in the lines on the same event at different books. One bet is called a "middle", which when a player finds two books that offer different point spreads for the same event. They will bet the more favorable spread at both books, and if the final score falls between the two, the bettor will win both bets. On the other hand, if the total falls outside the range of the "middle" the bettor only loses a small percentage of a bet (the "juice" or "vig" taken by the house).
For example, Book 1 has Team A as a 3-point favorite, and Book 2 has team B as a 3-point favorite. If a player bets Team B at Book 1, and Team A at Book 2, he will win both bets if either side wins by 2 or less points, and will win one bet and lose the other (known as a "side") if either team wins by 3 points.
Another strategy, known as arbitrage, or an "arb" or "scalp", involves finding different moneylines for the same event. In this case, the bettor will bet the more favorable line at both books, and have a guaranteed profit. For example, if Book 1 considers Team A to be worth +200 (2 to 1 underdog), and Book 2 considers Team B to be worth +200, a bettor can bet Team A at Book 1, and Team B at Book 2, and guarantee a 100% profit. This is a no-risk bet, as the player is guaranteed a profit no matter the result of the game.{{citation needed|date=October 2013}}
===Famous handicappers=== The first very well known sports handicapper in American culture was [[Jimmy Snyder (sports commentator)|Jimmy "The Greek" Snyder]].<ref>{{cite web|last=Pace|first=Eric|title=Jimmy "The Greek" Snyder; A Sports Oddsmaker|url=https://www.nytimes.com/1996/04/22/sports/jimmy-the-greek-snyder-76-is-dead-a-sports-oddsmaker.html|work=New York Times|accessdate=22 April 1996}}</ref> During his career he worked for [[CBS]] on their Sunday morning show, ''[[The NFL Today]]''. Because sports betting had a social taboo at the time, Snyder was not allowed to mention betting on games specifically. Instead, he would predict the score. Over the years the attitude towards sports betting, and handicapping in general, has changed. [[Billy Walters (gambler)|Billy Walters]] was profiled by ''[[60 Minutes]]'' because of his handicapping abilities.<ref>{{cite web|last=Logan|first=Lara|title=Sports Betting: Billy Walters|url=https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=d6FAUQ6SFKM|work=CBSNewsOnline|accessdate=16 Janueary 2011}}</ref> Billy Walters, and other unknown members of the Computer Group, developed a system for handicapping games and beating [[Las Vegas Valley|Las Vegas]] sportsbooks. ''[[The Huffington Post]]'' covered [[Jon Price]] a reclusive sports bettor that hires Ph.D's and works off of algorithmic information for his predictions.<ref>{{cite web|last=Jensen|first=David|title=Seeking PHD's Who Minor in Sports|url=http://www.huffingtonpost.com/david-jensen/hiring-guru-jon-price-see_b_8166112.html|work=The Huffington Post|accessdate=21 September 2015}}</ref> [[ESPN]] wrote an article on [[Haralabos Voulgaris]] naming him as the one of the premier [[National Basketball Association|NBA]] handicappers in the world.<ref>{{cite web|last=Eden|first=Scott|title=Meet The World's Top NBA Gambler|url=http://espn.go.com/blog/playbook/dollars/post/_/id/2935/meet-the-worlds-top-nba-gambler|work=ESPN The Magazine|publisher=ESPN|accessdate=21 Feb 2013}}</ref> He claims to have developed a system that uses advanced statistical analysis to predict the outcomes of games. In the past, very few people did any mathematical calculations when handicapping sporting events. [[Predictions]] were usually made from hunches or information not readily available to the public. However, with the advancement of technology computers powerful enough to run advanced simulation models now frequent homes and offices. Advanced statistics such as DVOA, Win Shares and Points per Possession are talked about in mainstream media. Brian Burke, author of The Fifth Down blog featured in the ''[[New York Times]]'', wrote a formula using advanced statistical techniques that has shown consistency correctly predicting [[National Football League|NFL]] winners.<ref>{{cite web|last=Burke|first=Brian|title=Game Probabilities Are Back|url=http://fifthdown.blogs.nytimes.com/2012/09/27/n-f-l-week-4-game-probabilities-are-back/|work=New York Times|publisher=New York Times|accessdate=27 September 2012}}</ref> Handicapping, as a profession, is very similar to being a [[stock analyst]]. Like [[Wall Street]] did in the 1970s, the sports handicapping industry is undergoing a quantitative revolution. Many successful handicappers also use money management systems similar to financial [[investment]] professionals. The most popular, and mathematically superior, system is the [[Kelly criterion]]. It is a formula for maximizing profits and minimizing losses based on payout odds and win probability of the underlying [[asset]].
==See also== *[[Political handicapping]] *[[Bookmaker]] *[[Handicap race (disambiguation)]] *[[Match fixing]] *[[Point shaving]] *[[Sports betting]] *[[Tipster]] *[[Handicap principle]]
==References== {{reflist}} * {{cite book | first=Andrew | last= Beyer| title=Picking Winners : A Horseplayer's Guide | publisher=Houghton Mifflin | date=May 6, 1994|edition=Reissue | isbn=0-395-70132-5}}
==External links== * [http://www.usga.org/Rule-Books/Handicap-System-Manual/Handicap-Manual/ United States Golf Association Handicap Manual] * [http://rldinvestments.com/Kelly%20Calculator/js/Money%20Management.html An Online Kelly Calculator] * [http://www.soccertipsters.net/asian-handicap Soccer Handicap info] * [http://www.verifiedsoccertips.com/asian-handicap-predictions Soccer prediction Handicap info]
